questions.text: A pediatrician examines a baby with a deficiency in fructose metabolism. Upon administration of a fructose bolus, the child becomes symptomatic and blood glucose levels begin to decrease. Which of the following will also occur after the administration of a fructose bolus in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: A fall in serum phosphate levels

options.label: B
options.text: A rise in cellular ATP levels

options.label: C
options.text: A sustained rise in serum fructose levels

options.label: D
options.text: An increase in the serum pH

questions.correct_answer: A. A fall in serum phosphate levels
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A fall in serum phosphate levels

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option A. A fall in serum phosphate levels:
  • • Option A. A fall in serum phosphate levels:
  • • Correct. When fructose is metabolized in the body, it is initially phosphorylated by fructokinase, leading to the consumption of ATP (adenosine triphosphate) and the release of inorganic phosphate (Pi). In patients with a deficiency in fructose metabolism, such as hereditary fructose intolerance, the inability to metabolize fructose can lead to a fall in serum phosphate levels as ATP is consumed during the futile cycling of fructose metabolism.
  • • Correct. When fructose is metabolized in the body, it is initially phosphorylated by fructokinase, leading to the consumption of ATP (adenosine triphosphate) and the release of inorganic phosphate (Pi). In patients with a deficiency in fructose metabolism, such as hereditary fructose intolerance, the inability to metabolize fructose can lead to a fall in serum phosphate levels as ATP is consumed during the futile cycling of fructose metabolism.
  • • Option B. A rise in cellular ATP levels:
  • • Option B. A rise in cellular ATP levels:
  • • This is not correct. In patients with fructose intolerance, ATP is actually consumed during the conversion of fructose to fructose-1-phosphate, so there is no rise in cellular ATP levels.
  • • This is not correct. In patients with fructose intolerance, ATP is actually consumed during the conversion of fructose to fructose-1-phosphate, so there is no rise in cellular ATP levels.
  • • Option C. A sustained rise in serum fructose levels:
  • • Option C. A sustained rise in serum fructose levels:
  • • This is not typically observed. Fructose is metabolized within cells, so sustained rises in serum fructose levels are not expected.
  • • This is not typically observed. Fructose is metabolized within cells, so sustained rises in serum fructose levels are not expected.
  • • Option D. An increase in the serum pH:
  • • Option D. An increase in the serum pH:
  • • This is not correct. Fructose metabolism in patients with fructose intolerance can lead to the accumulation of acidic intermediates, potentially causing a decrease in pH rather than an increase.
  • • This is not correct. Fructose metabolism in patients with fructose intolerance can lead to the accumulation of acidic intermediates, potentially causing a decrease in pH rather than an increase.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the metabolic consequences of fructose metabolism in patients with fructose intolerance, including the ATP consumption and fall in serum phosphate levels.

questions.text: A lady underwent vaginal hysterectomy for Carcinoma cervix. Following the surgery, after her urethral catheter was removed, she complained of leaking of urine. Methylene blue dye was instilled in her bladder through her urethra, and she was given oral Phenazopyridine dye. After some time, her pads were checked and it showed yellow staining at the top most pad, while the middle or bottom pads were unstained. She is likely to have:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ureterovaginal fistula

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • In this patient methylene blue dye was instilled in bladder and she was given oral phenazopyridine dye. The pad showed yellow staining at the top portion, but not the middle or bottom portions. She is likely to have Ureterovaginal fistula. The urine, which is being brought by ureters, is yellow due to oral intake of phenazopyridine which stains the urine yellow. The methylene blue which is in the bladder is not staining the swab as there is no Vesico or urethro-vaginal fistula.
  • • In this patient methylene blue dye was instilled in bladder and she was given oral phenazopyridine dye. The pad showed yellow staining at the top portion, but not the middle or bottom portions. She is likely to have Ureterovaginal fistula.
  • • The urine, which is being brought by ureters, is yellow due to oral intake of phenazopyridine which stains the urine yellow.
  • • The methylene blue which is in the bladder is not staining the swab as there is no Vesico or urethro-vaginal fistula.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents to the emergency department because of chest pain. He is found to have a large inferior wall myocardial infarction with 2mm ST-segment elevations in leads II, III, and aVF. ECG also demonstrates gradual lengthening of the PR interval until one QRS complex is dropped. He is sent to the cardiac catheterization laboratory, where a stent is placed in one of his major coronary arteries. In which coronary artery was the stent most likely placed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Right coronary artery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option D. Right Coronary artery (RCA) : The RCA typically supplies the right ventricle, the inferior part of the left ventricle, and the AV node in the majority of people (right-dominant circulation). Inferior MIs are most commonly associated with occlusion of the RCA, especially when AV nodal conduction abnormalities like the Mobitz Type I AV block are present, as the AV node's blood supply is often from the RCA in right-dominant hearts. Given the description of an inferior wall MI with associated AV nodal conduction disturbance (Mobitz Type I AV block), the stent was most likely placed in Right Coronary artery (RCA) .
  • • Option D.
  • • Right Coronary artery (RCA)
  • • Right Coronary artery (RCA)
  • • Option A. Diagonal branch of the LAD (Left Anterior Descending artery) : The diagonal branches supply the anterolateral portion of the left ventricle. An occlusion here would more likely result in anterior or anterolateral MI, not an inferior MI.
  • • Option A.
  • • Diagonal branch of the LAD (Left Anterior Descending artery)
  • • Option B. Left Anterior Descending artery (LAD) : The LAD primarily supplies the anterior wall of the left ventricle and the interventricular septum. Occlusion of the LAD would typically lead to an anterior MI, characterized by ST elevations in the anterior chest leads (V1-V4), not an inferior MI.
  • • Option B.
  • • Left Anterior Descending artery (LAD)
  • • Option C. Left Circumflex artery (LCx) : The LCx supplies the lateral wall of the left ventricle. While occlusion of the LCx can lead to lateral MI (evidenced by ST elevations in lateral leads I, aVL, V5, and V6), it is less commonly associated with inferior MI unless in cases where the LCx provides a significant supply to the inferior wall, which is less common and usually occurs in a left-dominant circulation.
  • • Option C.
  • • Left Circumflex artery (LCx)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key educational point is to understand the correlation between specific coronary artery occlusions and the corresponding areas of myocardial infarction, as well as associated ECG changes. An inferior wall MI with AV nodal conduction abnormalities, such as a Mobitz Type I AV block, typically implicates the RCA, especially in a right-dominant coronary circulation. This knowledge is crucial for the accurate diagnosis and appropriate management of patients with acute myocardial infarction.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents to the physician with arthritic pain in both knees along with back pain. He states that the pain has been present for months. In an effort to obtain relief, he has taken only aspirin, but this has been of little benefit. The patient is afebrile, and his slightly swollen knee joints are neither hot nor tender to palpation; however, the pain does restrict his motion. The cartilage of his ears appears slightly darker than normal. No tophi are present. A urine specimen is taken for analysis of uric acid content and turns black in the laboratory while standing. A defect in which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the patient’s condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Homogentisic acid oxidase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option C : Homogentisic acid oxidase - This enzyme is involved in the metabolism of tyrosine and phenylalanine. Deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase leads to alkaptonuria, a condition where homogentisic acid accumulates and darkens tissues, including cartilage and urine. The condition can cause ochronosis, leading to joint pain and darkening of cartilage.
  • • Option C
  • • Homogentisic acid oxidase
  • • Option A : α -Ketoacid dehydrogenase - This enzyme is involved in the catabolism of branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs). Deficiency of this enzyme can lead to maple syrup urine disease (MSUD), which presents with neurological symptoms and characteristic sweet-smelling urine. It is not directly related to the patient's joint pain and black urine.
  • • Option A
  • • α -Ketoacid dehydrogenase
  • • Option B : Galactokinase - Galactokinase is involved in the metabolism of galactose, and deficiency of this enzyme can lead to galactokinase deficiency (part of galactosemia). This condition can cause cataracts but is not associated with joint pain or black urine.
  • • Option B
  • • Galactokinase
  • • Option D : Phenylalanine hydroxylase - Phenylalanine hydroxylase is involved in the metabolism of phenylalanine. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to phenylketonuria (PKU), which is characterized by elevated levels of phenylalanine in the blood. PKU can cause intellectual disability and other neurological symptoms but is not directly related to joint pain or black urine.
  • • Option D
  • • Phenylalanine hydroxylase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ This question assesses knowledge of alkaptonuria, a rare autosomal recessive metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase. This enzyme normally breaks down homogentisic acid, but its deficiency leads to the accumulation of homogentisic acid in various tissues, causing darkening of the cartilage (ochronosis) and dark urine that turns black upon exposure to air. The patient's joint pain is due to ochronotic arthritis, which occurs as a result of the deposition of homogentisic acid in joint tissues. Understanding the genetic and metabolic basis of alkaptonuria is important for recognizing and diagnosing this condition in clinical practice.

questions.text: Following a devastating hurricane in a tropical region, public health officials are on high alert for the potential outbreak of infectious diseases among the affected population. In the chaotic aftermath, with flooding and displacement of communities, there is a heightened risk for various infections due to exposure to contaminated water, overcrowding in shelters, and disruption of sanitation services. Considering the environmental and social conditions prevalent after such a disaster, which of the following diseases is least likely to cause an epidemic in the immediate aftermath?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Leishmaniasis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Leishmaniasis is a disease caused by protozoan parasites of the genus Leishmania, transmitted to humans by the bite of infected female phlebotomine sandflies. The transmission of leishmaniasis is more dependent on the presence and behavior of the vector (sandflies) rather than the direct aftermath of a disaster such as a hurricane. Unlike the other diseases listed, which can be directly influenced by the conditions following a disaster (e.g., contaminated water, overcrowding, poor sanitation), leishmaniasis transmission does not typically increase immediately following such events, as it requires specific ecological conditions suitable for the sandfly vector.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Leptospirosis : This disease is often associated with flooding and exposure to contaminated water, conditions that are common after disasters like hurricanes. The bacteria can enter the human body through cuts or abrasions in the skin or through mucous membranes, making it a significant risk in post-disaster settings.
  • • Option A. Leptospirosis
  • • Option B. Rickettsiosis : Diseases caused by Rickettsia bacteria can be transmitted by various vectors, including ticks, fleas, and lice, which might proliferate or come into closer contact with humans due to the environmental disruption and displacement caused by disasters.
  • • Option B. Rickettsiosis
  • • Option D. Acute respiratory infection (ARI) : The overcrowding in shelters and the stress on sanitation and healthcare services following a disaster can facilitate the transmission of pathogens causing ARIs. The close quarters and compromised living conditions make ARIs one of the most common health concerns in the aftermath of disasters.
  • • Option D. Acute respiratory infection (ARI)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diseases common in Post-disaster Phase
  • ➤ Diseases common in Post-disaster Phase
  • ➤ Gastroenteritis (MC) Acute respiratory tract infections (Pneumonias) Leptospirosis Rickettsiosis Rabies Equine encephalitis
  • ➤ Gastroenteritis (MC)
  • ➤ Acute respiratory tract infections (Pneumonias)
  • ➤ Leptospirosis
  • ➤ Rickettsiosis
  • ➤ Rabies
  • ➤ Equine encephalitis

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with symptoms of kidney dysfunction, including fluid retention and elevated blood pressure. Further investigations reveal abnormalities in glomerular function. The healthcare provider suspects mesangial cell involvement. All of the following will cause mesangial contraction in the kidneys, except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cyclic Adenosine Monophosphate (cAMP)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Platelet-Derived Growth Factor (PDGF) is a growth factor that is involved in various cellular processes , including the regulation of mesangial cell activity in the kidneys . PDGF can cause mesangial cell contraction , which can lead to changes in GFR and blood flow .
  • • Option A.
  • • Platelet-Derived Growth Factor (PDGF)
  • • growth factor
  • • cellular processes
  • • regulation
  • • mesangial cell activity
  • • kidneys
  • • mesangial cell contraction
  • • changes
  • • GFR
  • • blood flow
  • • Option C. Prostaglandin F2 (PGF2) are lipid compounds with diverse effects in the body. PGF2 is known to induce mesangial cell contraction in the kidneys . This contraction can affect the glomerular filtration rate and renal blood flow .
  • • Option C.
  • • Prostaglandin F2 (PGF2)
  • • lipid compounds
  • • induce mesangial cell contraction
  • • kidneys
  • • affect
  • • glomerular filtration rate
  • • renal blood flow
  • • Option D. Platelet-Activating Factor (PAF) is a potent inflammatory mediator . PAF can stimulate mesangial cell contraction , which can impact the regulation of glomerular filtration and renal function .
  • • Option D.
  • • Platelet-Activating Factor (PAF)
  • • potent inflammatory mediator
  • • stimulate mesangial cell contraction
  • • impact
  • • regulation
  • • glomerular filtration
  • • renal function

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Understand the role of various substances, including PDGF , PGF2 , and PAF in inducing mesangial cell contraction and their impact on renal function , while recognizing that cAMP is not typically associated with mesangial cell contraction in the kidneys.
  • ➤ PDGF
  • ➤ PGF2
  • ➤ PAF
  • ➤ inducing mesangial cell contraction
  • ➤ renal function
  • ➤ Ref : Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 25 th edition, page no. 678
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 25 th edition, page no. 678

questions.text: Identify the following investigation.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Colour Doppler

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option B: Colour Doppler Ultrasound : This is the correct choice for evaluating portal venous flow. Colour Doppler ultrasound is highly sensitive for detecting blood flow direction and velocity within the vessels. It is particularly useful in assessing the portal venous system for signs of portal hypertension, such as the reversal of flow (hepatofugal flow), which indicates significant portal hypertension. Colour Doppler can also help in identifying collateral vessels and varices that may develop due to portal hypertension.
  • • Option B: Colour Doppler Ultrasound
  • • Option A: B-mode Ultrasound (USG) : B-mode (Brightness mode) ultrasound provides grayscale images that depict the structural details of organs and tissues. While it is useful for evaluating liver morphology and identifying features of cirrhosis and ascites, B-mode USG alone cannot assess blood flow or its direction within the portal venous system.
  • • Option A:
  • • B-mode Ultrasound (USG)
  • • Option C: M-Mode Ultrasound (USG) : M-Mode (Motion mode) ultrasound captures the motion of organ structures and is primarily used in cardiac imaging to assess the movement of heart structures over time. It is not suitable for evaluating blood flow in the portal venous system or detecting changes in flow direction related to portal hypertension.
  • • Option C:
  • • M-Mode Ultrasound (USG)
  • • Option D: A-Mode Ultrasound (USG) : A-Mode (Amplitude mode) ultrasound provides one-dimensional information and is mainly used in ophthalmology and some superficial structures. It is not appropriate for assessing portal venous flow or diagnosing portal hypertension.
  • • Option D:
  • • A-Mode Ultrasound (USG)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to understand the utility of various ultrasound modalities in the evaluation of portal hypertension, with a focus on Colour Doppler ultrasound as the most sensitive and appropriate modality for detecting changes in the direction and velocity of portal venous flow. Recognizing the shift from hepatopetal to hepatofugal flow is crucial for diagnosing portal hypertension and managing complications related to chronic liver diseases, such as cirrhosis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to the physician with right-sided Horner syndrome and facial pain, a hoarse voice, dysarthria, diplopia, numbness, and ataxia with contralateral impairment of pain and temperature sensation in her arm and leg. No other motor or hearing deficits are evident. Which parts of the central nervous system are involved in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Caudal lateral pontine tegmentum, including spinal tegmental tract of cranial nerve V, and the inferior surface of the cerebellum

options.label: C
options.text: Dorsolateral quadrant of the medulla and the inferior surface of the cerebellum

options.label: D
options.text: Internal capsule, caudate nucleus, putamen, and globus pallidus

questions.correct_answer: C. Dorsolateral quadrant of the medulla and the inferior surface of the cerebellum
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dorsolateral quadrant of the medulla and the inferior surface of the cerebellum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option C. Dorsolateral quadrant of the medulla and the inferior surface of the cerebellum : This is the correct answer. Wallenberg syndrome typically involves the dorsolateral quadrant of the medulla, affecting the structures mentioned above, and may involve cerebellar structures due to compromised blood flow in the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) territory. Therefore, the parts of the central nervous system involved in this patient's condition are most consistent with Dorsolateral quadrant of the medulla and the inferior surface of the cerebellum .
  • • Option C.
  • • Dorsolateral quadrant of the medulla and the inferior surface of the cerebellum
  • • Dorsolateral quadrant of the medulla and the inferior surface of the cerebellum
  • • Option A. Caudal lateral pontine tegmentum, including spinal tegmental tract of cranial nerve V, and the inferior surface of the cerebellum : This location is too rostral and does not correspond with the medullary findings typical of Wallenberg syndrome.
  • • Option A.
  • • Caudal lateral pontine tegmentum, including spinal tegmental tract of cranial nerve V, and the inferior surface of the cerebellum
  • • Option B. Cochlea and vestibular apparatus : These structures are involved in hearing and balance and would not explain the constellation of symptoms seen in Wallenberg syndrome.
  • • Option B.
  • • Cochlea and vestibular apparatus
  • • Option D. Internal capsule, caudate nucleus, putamen, and globus pallidus : These structures are part of the basal ganglia and internal capsule in the brain, which, if involved, would typically present with different symptoms, including more pronounced motor deficits.
  • • Option D.
  • • Internal capsule, caudate nucleus, putamen, and globus pallidus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To recognize the clinical presentation and involved anatomical structures of lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome). This syndrome is characterized by a constellation of symptoms including Horner syndrome, dysphagia, hoarseness, contralateral pain, and temperature sensory loss, and ipsilateral ataxia, reflecting involvement of the dorsolateral medulla oblongata and associated structures.

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of skin itching and a rash following a camping trip. He reports contact with soil and water bodies. Which of the following parasites is least likely to have entered his body through the skin?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)   Trichinella

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Trichinella, known for causing trichinellosis, typically enters the human body through the ingestion of undercooked or raw meat containing Trichinella larvae, not through skin penetration.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Ancylostoma : Incorrect, as Ancylostoma duodenale can penetrate the skin.
  • • Option
  • • A. Ancylostoma
  • • Option B. Strongyloides : Incorrect, Strongyloides stercoralis is known for skin penetration.
  • • Option
  • • B. Strongyloides
  • • Option D. Necator : Incorrect, Necator americanus, can also penetrate the skin.
  • • Option
  • • D. Necator

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trichinella, the causative agent of trichinellosis, is typically transmitted through the ingestion of undercooked or raw meat containing Trichinella larvae. In contrast, Ancylostoma duodenale (a type of hookworm), Strongyloides stercoralis, and Necator americanus (another hookworm) are known for their ability to penetrate the skin, distinguishing them from Trichinella.

questions.text: A 23-year-old primi presents in labor. She is an unbooked patient and by her LMP, she is 42 weeks and 4 days. On examination, she is 6 cm dilated, well-effaced and the vertex is at 0 station. A CTG taken is as shown below. What could be the reason for the findings in the CTG shown below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Oligohydramnios

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The patient is post term, in labor and the CTG is showing variable decelerations (as there is no relation between the decelerations and the uterine contractions). Variable decelerations occur because of cord compression which is seen in oligohydramnios which is seen in post term pregnancy.
  • • The patient is post term, in labor and the CTG is showing variable decelerations (as there is no relation between the decelerations and the uterine contractions).
  • • Variable decelerations occur because of cord compression which is seen in oligohydramnios which is seen in post term pregnancy.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A: Cord prolapse will usually present with prolonged deceleration/ fetal bradycardia/fetal death. Option B: Meconium, if associated with fetal hypoxia will present with later decelerations. Option D: Uteroplacental insufficiency will present as late decelerations.
  • • Option A: Cord prolapse will usually present with prolonged deceleration/ fetal bradycardia/fetal death.
  • • Option A:
  • • Option B: Meconium, if associated with fetal hypoxia will present with later decelerations.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option D: Uteroplacental insufficiency will present as late decelerations.
  • • Option D:

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the primary care office because she has had worsening of numbness and tingling in her right hand over the past four months. During the past week, she also has had shooting pains from the wrist to the hand that waken her from sleep. On physical examination, results of Phalen and Tinel tests are positive. Which of the following studies of the wrists and hands is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nerve conduction studies

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option C. Nerve Conduction Studies : This test measures the speed of electrical impulses through the nerves. In the context of carpal tunnel syndrome, it can specifically assess the function of the median nerve and is considered the gold standard for diagnosing this condition. It can quantify the degree of nerve impairment.
  • • Option C.
  • • Nerve Conduction Studies
  • • Option A. CT Scan : Computed tomography (CT) scans provide excellent detail of the bones and joints but are less effective for assessing soft tissues like nerves. It is not the preferred method for diagnosing carpal tunnel syndrome, which involves compression of the median nerve.
  • • Option A.
  • • CT Scan
  • • Option B. MRI : Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is very effective for visualizing soft tissue and can detect changes in the wrist structure and surrounding tissues. While it can be used in the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome, it is not typically the first-line diagnostic tool due to its higher cost and limited availability compared to other methods.
  • • Option B.
  • • MRI
  • • Option D. Ultrasonography : Ultrasound can visualize the median nerve and can be used to diagnose carpal tunnel syndrome by measuring the size of the nerve and observing its movement. However, it is less definitive and operator-dependent compared to nerve conduction studies.
  • • Option D.
  • • Ultrasonography

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nerve conduction studies are the most appropriate diagnostic test for confirming carpal tunnel syndrome, as they specifically assess the function of the median nerve and can quantify the degree of nerve impairment. This helps in distinguishing carpal tunnel syndrome from other conditions that might cause similar symptoms.

questions.text: A public health department is evaluating the impact of a universal vaccination program on the incidence of a viral illness within the community. The department utilizes a conceptual framework to assess the overall health outcomes, as shown in below mentioned diagram. Based on the information provided in the diagram, which model of disease causation does it represent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sufficient component cause model

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Sufficient-Component Cause Model is depicted in the image. This model is used to explain how diseases occur due to a combination of different factors, none of which are necessary or sufficient on their own to cause the disease, but when combined, they complete the "causal pie." Each slice represents a component cause, and a full pie represents a sufficient cause for the disease to manifest.
  • • In the context of vaccination, this model helps to understand how immunization can remove a component cause (being unvaccinated), potentially preventing the completion of a sufficient cause and thus reducing the incidence of disease.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. The Epidemiological triad model focuses on the interaction between the agent, the host, and the environment, which is not clearly depicted in the given image.
  • • Option B.
  • • Epidemiological triad
  • • Option C. The PERT (Program Evaluation and Review Technique) model is a project management tool used for planning and controlling large projects, not for disease causation.
  • • Option C.
  • • PERT
  • • (Program Evaluation and Review Technique)
  • • model
  • • Option D. The Web of causation model illustrates a complex set of connections between various factors that contribute to the development of a disease, usually represented as a web, which is different from the pie charts shown in the image.
  • • Option D.
  • • Web of causation model

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sufficient component cause model
  • ➤ Sufficient component cause model
  • ➤ It was developed by Rothman based on the idea that an outcome can only happen when a sufficient cause is present The complete pie, which might be considered a causal pathway, is called a sufficient cause The individual factors are called component causes A component that appears in every pie or pathway is called a necessary cause, because without it, disease does not occur
  • ➤ It was developed by Rothman based on the idea that an outcome can only happen when a sufficient cause is present
  • ➤ The complete pie, which might be considered a causal pathway, is called a sufficient cause
  • ➤ The individual factors are called component causes
  • ➤ A component that appears in every pie or pathway is called a necessary cause, because without it, disease does not occur
  • ➤ A disease may have more than one sufficient cause, with each sufficient cause being composed of several component causes that may or may not overlap

questions.text: In a recent clinical review aimed at identifying patients at high risk for a particular cardiovascular condition, two experienced clinicians, Dr. A and Dr. B, evaluated 115 patient profiles. Each clinician was asked to independently assess the profiles and categorize them as either high risk ("High Risk") or not high risk ("Low Risk"). Their assessments resulted in agreement on 35 profiles being categorized as "High Risk" and 40 profiles as "Low Risk." Dr. A considered 50 profiles as "High Risk" while Dr. B identified 60 profiles as "High Risk." Based on this data, calculate the Kappa statistic to quantify the level of agreement between Dr. A and Dr. B, beyond what might be expected by chance.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 0.31

Explanation:

  • • Explanation -
  • • 2x2 contingency table based on the information provided:
  • • Calculation
  • • Calculation
  • • Step 1 : Calculate O (the observed agreement):
  • • Step 1
  • • 35 were considered High risk by both. 40 were considered Low risk by both. So, O = Number in agreement/total = (35 + 40)/115 = 0.65
  • • 35 were considered High risk by both.
  • • 40 were considered Low risk by both. So, O = Number in agreement/total = (35 + 40)/115 = 0.65
  • • Step 2 : Find the probability that randomly both consider risk factor as High Risk.
  • • Step 2
  • • Dr A for High risk to 50/115 images, or 43% (0.43)
  • • Dr B for High risk to 60/115 images, or 52% (0.52)
  • • Total probability of both saying high risk randomly is: 0.43 × 0.52 = 0.22
  • • Step 3 : Calculate the probability that randomly both say Low risk.
  • • Step 3
  • • Dr A - 65/115 images, or 56% (0.56)
  • • Dr B - 55/115 images, or 48% (0.48)
  • • Total probability of both saying Low risk, randomly is: 0.56 × 0.48 = 0.27
  • • Step 4 : Calculate E. Adding answers from Step 2 and 3 to get the overall probability that the clinicians would randomly agree. E = 0.22 + 0.27 = 0.49
  • • Step 4
  • • Step 5 : K = O-E/(1 – E) = (0.65 – 0.49)/(1 – 0.49) = 0.31
  • • Step 5
  • • The Kappa statistic of approximately 0.31 indicates a fair level of agreement between Dr. A and Dr. B, beyond what would be expected by chance. This suggests that their assessments are somewhat consistent, but there is still a considerable amount of disagreement that could be due to subjective interpretation of the patient profiles or differing thresholds for what constitutes "High Risk."

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Kappa coefficient (K) - Indicates the extent of agreement between frequencies of two sets of data collected on two different occasions
  • ➤ Kappa coefficient (K) -
  • ➤ Formula: K = O-E/(1 – E)
  • ➤ Interpretation:
  • ➤ Interpretation:
  • ➤ 0 = agreement equivalent to chance. 0 – 0.20 = slight agreement. 0.21 – 0.40 = fair agreement. 0.41 – 0.60 = moderate agreement. 0.61 – 0.80 = substantial agreement. 0.81 – 0.99 = near perfect agreement 1 = perfect agreement.
  • ➤ 0 = agreement equivalent to chance.
  • ➤ 0 – 0.20 = slight agreement.
  • ➤ 0.21 – 0.40 = fair agreement.
  • ➤ 0.41 – 0.60 = moderate agreement.
  • ➤ 0.61 – 0.80 = substantial agreement.
  • ➤ 0.81 – 0.99 = near perfect agreement
  • ➤ 1 = perfect agreement.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to her physician with concerns that she is unable to produce breast milk, despite having given birth approximately one month ago. On further questioning, she indicates she has been exceptionally thirsty lately, and describes feelings of fatigue and cold intolerance. Physical examination reveals no abnormalities except a scarcity of axillary hair. Laboratory tests reveal a serum sodium level of 150 mEq/L and urinalysis reveals a urine osmolality of 220 mOsmol/kg. Which of the following most likely increased the patient’s risk of developing this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Abnormalities of the placenta

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option A) Abnormalities of the placenta : Placental abnormalities, such as placenta previa or placental abruption, can lead to significant obstetric hemorrhage, which is a risk factor for Sheehan's syndrome. Severe blood loss during childbirth can impair blood supply to the pituitary gland, leading to its necrosis.
  • • Option A)
  • • Abnormalities of the placenta
  • • Option B) Alcohol intake during pregnancy : While excessive alcohol intake during pregnancy is associated with fetal alcohol syndrome and other complications, it is not directly linked to an increased risk of postpartum hemorrhage or pituitary gland necrosis.
  • • Option
  • • B)
  • • Alcohol intake during pregnancy
  • • Option C) Endometriosis : Endometriosis is a condition in which endometrial-like tissue grows outside the uterus, causing pain and potentially affecting fertility. However, it is not typically associated with an increased risk of postpartum hemorrhage or pituitary gland necrosis.
  • • Option
  • • C)
  • • Endometriosis
  • • Option D) Gestational diabetes : Gestational diabetes is a condition of glucose intolerance that arises during pregnancy. While it can lead to certain complications such as macrosomia (large-for-gestational-age babies) and potentially difficult deliveries, it is not a direct risk factor for postpartum hemorrhage or pituitary gland necrosis.
  • • Option
  • • D)
  • • Gestational diabetes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to recognize the clinical features of Sheehan's syndrome and understand its association with severe postpartum hemorrhage. Identifying risk factors for obstetric hemorrhage, such as placental abnormalities, is crucial for preventing this potentially life-threatening complication and its long-term sequelae, including Sheehan's syndrome.

questions.text: In a ventriculoperitoneal shunt surgery, the upper end of the shunt is inserted into:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lateral ventricles

questions.text: A nutritionist is counseling a patient on dietary choices to support weight management and metabolic health. During the consultation, the nutritionist explains the concept of the thermic effect of food (TEF), which refers to the energy expenditure associated with digesting, absorbing, and metabolizing nutrients. Understanding that different macronutrients have varying thermic effects can be crucial in designing an effective diet plan. Based on this information, which of the following types of diets is associated with the highest thermic effect?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Protein diet

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The thermic effect of food (TEF) is highest for protein compared to carbohydrates and fats. The energy required to digest, absorb, and metabolize protein is greater, often cited as approximately 20-30% of the energy content of the protein consumed. This increased energy expenditure contributes to the higher thermic effect of a protein diet, making it a key factor in weight management and metabolic health strategies.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Carbohydrate diet : Carbohydrates have a moderate thermic effect, generally lower than that of protein, typically around 5-15% of the energy content.
  • • Option A. Carbohydrate diet
  • • Option C. Fat diet : Fats have the lowest thermic effect among the macronutrients, usually about 0-3% of the energy content, making their thermic effect significantly less than that of proteins.
  • • Option C. Fat diet
  • • Option D. Vitamin diet : Vitamins do not have a direct thermic effect comparable to macronutrients like proteins, carbohydrates, and fats. Their role in metabolism is crucial, but they do not directly contribute to the thermic effect of food in the same way.
  • • Option D. Vitamin diet

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Specific dynamic action (SDA) [Thermic effect of food (TEF)/Dietary induced thermogenesis (DIT)]
  • ➤ Specific dynamic action (SDA) [Thermic effect of food (TEF)/Dietary induced thermogenesis (DIT)]
  • ➤ TEF is the amount of energy expenditure above the basal metabolic rate due to the cost of processing food for use and storage TEF is the energy required for digestion, absorption, and disposal of ingested nutrients TEF magnitude depends on the composition of food consumed: Proteins (20-30% of energy consumed > Carbohydrates (5-15%) > Fats (0-3%) A thermic effect of 30% for proteins means that 100 calories of protein only end up as 70 usable calories
  • ➤ TEF is the amount of energy expenditure above the basal metabolic rate due to the cost of processing food for use and storage
  • ➤ TEF is the energy required for digestion, absorption, and disposal of ingested nutrients
  • ➤ TEF magnitude depends on the composition of food consumed: Proteins (20-30% of energy consumed > Carbohydrates (5-15%) > Fats (0-3%)
  • ➤ A thermic effect of 30% for proteins means that 100 calories of protein only end up as 70 usable calories

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with redness, pain, and decreased vision in her right eye. She has a history of contact lens wear and reports sleeping in them occasionally. On examination, there is a white infiltrate in the cornea and a small hypopyon. Fluorescein staining result shows in the image below. No discharge is noted. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent of her corneal infection?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)  Herpes simplex virus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The presence of a dendritic ulcer on fluorescein staining is highly suggestive of herpes simplex virus infection.
  • • Herpes keratoconjunctivitis is primarily caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV)-1, transmitted through kissing or close personal contact. HSV-2, known for genital infections, can also affect the eyes in adults through oculo-genital contact.
  • • The disease presents in two main forms:
  • • The disease presents in two main forms:
  • • Conjunctivitis : This presents as follicular conjunctivitis, often accompanying herpes lesions on the face and eyelids, and is typically associated with preauricular lymphadenopathy. Keratitis : This involves corneal damage and can manifest in various forms : Epithelial keratitis : Characterized by patterns like epithelial punctate keratitis, dendritic ulcers (irregular, zigzag linear branching shaped), and geographical ulcers. Stromal keratitis : This is the involvement of the corneal stroma. Additionally, herpes keratoconjunctivitis can lead to uveitis, presenting as non-granulomatous iridocyclitis
  • • Conjunctivitis : This presents as follicular conjunctivitis, often accompanying herpes lesions on the face and eyelids, and is typically associated with preauricular lymphadenopathy.
  • • Conjunctivitis
  • • Keratitis : This involves corneal damage and can manifest in various forms :
  • • Keratitis
  • • various forms
  • • Epithelial keratitis : Characterized by patterns like epithelial punctate keratitis, dendritic ulcers (irregular, zigzag linear branching shaped), and geographical ulcers.
  • • Epithelial keratitis
  • • Stromal keratitis : This is the involvement of the corneal stroma.
  • • Stromal keratitis
  • • Additionally, herpes keratoconjunctivitis can lead to uveitis, presenting as non-granulomatous iridocyclitis
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Staphylococcus aureus - Commonly causes blepharitis and can cause keratitis, but not typically associated with dendritic ulcers.
  • • Option
  • • A. Staphylococcus aureus
  • • Option C. Pseudomonas aeruginosa - A serious cause of keratitis in contact lens wearers but more commonly presents with rapid, aggressive infection and corneal ulceration without dendritic ulcers.
  • • Option
  • • C. Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  • • For option A & C - Bacterial keratitis, primarily caused by S. aureus, Pseudomonas, and Streptococcus pneumoniae. Infection reaches the cornea endogenously from adjacent structures or exogenously from water or air, leading to purulent corneal ulcers characterized by eye pain, blurred vision, and yellowish-white lesions. Pseudomonas infections are particularly aggressive, potentially causing rapid corneal damage.
  • • For option A & C
  • • Laboratory diagnosis - corneal scraping for culture and microscopy Treatment - Topical antibiotics, such as Cefazolin and Tobramycin, with frequent instillation, and in severe cases, systemic antibiotics like cephalosporin.
  • • Laboratory diagnosis - corneal scraping for culture and microscopy
  • • Laboratory diagnosis - corneal scraping for culture and microscopy
  • • Treatment - Topical antibiotics, such as Cefazolin and Tobramycin, with frequent instillation, and in severe cases, systemic antibiotics like cephalosporin.
  • • Treatment
  • • Option D. Acanthamoeba - Acanthamoeba keratitis is an ocular infection often linked to contact lens use. These amoebae can adhere to the corneal epithelium, especially in cases of corneal injury or post-surgery, leading to severe ocular problems like corneal ulcers, iritis, and vision loss.
  • • Option
  • • D. Acanthamoeba
  • • Laboratory diagnosis - corneal scrapings examined under wet mount, revealing trophozoites and cysts, and further confirmed by PCR. Treatment - Topical antiseptics such as 0.1% propamidine and in severe cases, penetrating keratoplasty.
  • • Laboratory diagnosis - corneal scrapings examined under wet mount, revealing trophozoites and cysts, and further confirmed by PCR.
  • • Laboratory diagnosis
  • • Treatment - Topical antiseptics such as 0.1% propamidine and in severe cases, penetrating keratoplasty.
  • • Treatment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The patient's symptoms and clinical findings are indicative of keratitis, specifically herpetic keratitis. The presence of a dendritic ulcer on fluorescein staining is highly suggestive of herpes simplex virus infection. This virus is a common cause of corneal infection, especially in the context of contact lens wear.

questions.text: Drug Y shown in figure represents:
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Rasburicase

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the emergency department after being bitten by a street dog. On examination, there is a 1.5 cm abrasion on the child's arm with slight oozing. The emergency physician must quickly determine the appropriate post-exposure prophylaxis. Which of the following statements regarding the management of this dog bite is correct? The wound is classified as a Category 3 exposure. The wound should be washed with normal tap water for 15-20 minutes. The wound should be cleaned with spirit. The wound requires loose suturing with proper dressing. Equine immunoglobulin is administered at a dose of 40 IU/kg of body weight, twice. The intradermal rabies vaccine should be given on days 0, 3, 7, 28.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 6

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The correct management of a dog bite from a street dog includes:
  • • The correct management of a dog bite from a street dog includes:
  • • Category 3 wound (1): This is the most severe category and includes single or multiple transdermal bites or scratches, licks on broken skin, contamination of mucous membrane with saliva from licks, and exposure due to direct contact with bats. Immediate vaccination and administration of rabies immunoglobulin are warranted. Wash the wound with normal tap water for 15-20 minutes (2): Immediate and thorough washing of the wound with soap and water for at least 15 minutes is crucial to reduce the viral load. This is a recommended first-aid measure for all categories of exposure. Clean the wound with spirit (3): Cleaning the wound with an antiseptic like spirit (ethyl alcohol) can help to further reduce the risk of infection. Intradermal vaccine on days 0, 3, 7, 28 (6): According to the updated rabies post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) guidelines, the intradermal vaccination schedule (2-2-2-2-2) is recommended on days 0, 3, 7, and 28 should be given with HRIG or ERIG single dose
  • • Category 3 wound (1): This is the most severe category and includes single or multiple transdermal bites or scratches, licks on broken skin, contamination of mucous membrane with saliva from licks, and exposure due to direct contact with bats. Immediate vaccination and administration of rabies immunoglobulin are warranted.
  • • Category 3 wound (1):
  • • Wash the wound with normal tap water for 15-20 minutes (2): Immediate and thorough washing of the wound with soap and water for at least 15 minutes is crucial to reduce the viral load. This is a recommended first-aid measure for all categories of exposure.
  • • Wash the wound with normal tap water for 15-20 minutes (2):
  • • Clean the wound with spirit (3): Cleaning the wound with an antiseptic like spirit (ethyl alcohol) can help to further reduce the risk of infection.
  • • Clean the wound with spirit (3):
  • • Intradermal vaccine on days 0, 3, 7, 28 (6): According to the updated rabies post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) guidelines, the intradermal vaccination schedule (2-2-2-2-2) is recommended on days 0, 3, 7, and 28 should be given with HRIG or ERIG single dose
  • • Intradermal vaccine on days 0, 3, 7, 28 (6):
  • • Note - Prophylactic antibiotics (usually amoxicillin-clavulanate) should be given to asplenic individuals who have been bitten by a dog, even in the absence of infectious symptoms. Amoxicillin and clavulanate is first-line therapy for the prophylactic treatment of dog, human, and cat bites along with Appropriate tetanus and rabies prophylaxis
  • • Note
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Loose suturing of the wound with proper dressing (4): This is not recommended for Category 3 wounds due to the risk of rabies virus proliferation at the wound site. If suturing is required for other medical reasons, it should be done after administering rabies immunoglobulin and the first dose of the rabies vaccine. Equine immunoglobulin at a dose of 40 IU/kg body weight, twice (5): This is incorrect. Rabies immunoglobulin (either equine or human) is given only once, at the beginning of post-exposure prophylaxis (RIg is NOT recommended beyond the 7th day of starting first dose of vaccine), to provide immediate passive immunity until the patient's active immunity develops in response to the rabies vaccine.
  • • Loose suturing of the wound with proper dressing (4): This is not recommended for Category 3 wounds due to the risk of rabies virus proliferation at the wound site. If suturing is required for other medical reasons, it should be done after administering rabies immunoglobulin and the first dose of the rabies vaccine.
  • • Loose suturing of the wound with proper dressing (4):
  • • Equine immunoglobulin at a dose of 40 IU/kg body weight, twice (5): This is incorrect. Rabies immunoglobulin (either equine or human) is given only once, at the beginning of post-exposure prophylaxis (RIg is NOT recommended beyond the 7th day of starting first dose of vaccine), to provide immediate passive immunity until the patient's active immunity develops in response to the rabies vaccine.
  • • Equine immunoglobulin at a dose of 40 IU/kg body weight, twice (5):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Post Exposure Prophylaxis of Rabies Guidelines
  • ➤ Post Exposure Prophylaxis of Rabies Guidelines
  • ➤ Category-wise PEP measures:
  • ➤ Category-wise PEP measures:
  • ➤ Category I wound : None Category II wound : Local treatment of wound + Immediate vaccination Category III wound : Local treatment of wound + Immediate vaccination + Immediate immunoglobulin
  • ➤ Category I wound : None
  • ➤ Category I wound
  • ➤ Category II wound : Local treatment of wound + Immediate vaccination
  • ➤ Category II wound
  • ➤ Category III wound : Local treatment of wound + Immediate vaccination + Immediate immunoglobulin
  • ➤ Category III wound
  • ➤ PEP is discontinued if:
  • ➤ PEP is discontinued if:
  • ➤ Suspected animal proved free of rabies by an appropriate laboratory In case of domestic animal, latter remains healthy throughout 10-day observation period from day of bite
  • ➤ Suspected animal proved free of rabies by an appropriate laboratory
  • ➤ In case of domestic animal, latter remains healthy throughout 10-day observation period from day of bite
  • ➤ Rabies Immunoglobulin is NOT indicated in previously vaccinated individuals

questions.text: A 29-year-old previously healthy man has the onset of episodic generalized tonic-clonic seizures that continue for 3 weeks. On physical examination, he is afebrile. He has mild weakness in his left arm. A head CT scan reveals a mass lesion with surrounding hemorrhage in the right cerebral hemisphere. A sterotactic biopsy is performed, and the high power microscopic appearance of the lesion is shown here. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option A. Organizing cerebral abscess:
  • • Option A. Organizing cerebral abscess:
  • • Organizing cerebral abscess typically presents with an encapsulated lesion in the brain, often with a history of infection or systemic illness. The histopathological appearance of organizing abscess usually includes a fibrous capsule and necrotic debris in the center.
  • • Organizing cerebral abscess typically presents with an encapsulated lesion in the brain, often with a history of infection or systemic illness. The histopathological appearance of organizing abscess usually includes a fibrous capsule and necrotic debris in the center.
  • • Option B. Herpes simplex encephalitis:
  • • Option B. Herpes simplex encephalitis:
  • • Herpes simplex encephalitis is characterized by viral infection of the brain, often leading to necrosis and inflammation of the temporal lobes. The histopathology in herpes encephalitis typically shows viral inclusions and a lymphocytic infiltrate.
  • • Herpes simplex encephalitis is characterized by viral infection of the brain, often leading to necrosis and inflammation of the temporal lobes. The histopathology in herpes encephalitis typically shows viral inclusions and a lymphocytic infiltrate.
  • • Option C. Berry aneurysm:
  • • Option C. Berry aneurysm:
  • • Berry aneurysms are vascular abnormalities that can lead to subarachnoid hemorrhage when they rupture. They are not typically associated with mass lesions or surrounding hemorrhage.
  • • Berry aneurysms are vascular abnormalities that can lead to subarachnoid hemorrhage when they rupture. They are not typically associated with mass lesions or surrounding hemorrhage.
  • • Option D. Vascular malformation:
  • • Option D. Vascular malformation:
  • • Vascular malformations, such as arteriovenous malformations (AVMs), can lead to intracerebral hemorrhage. Histopathologically, AVMs consist of abnormal clusters of arteries and veins.
  • • Vascular malformations, such as arteriovenous malformations (AVMs), can lead to intracerebral hemorrhage. Histopathologically, AVMs consist of abnormal clusters of arteries and veins.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vascular malformations, such as arteriovenous malformations (AVMs), are abnormal clusters of arteries and veins in the brain. They can lead to intracerebral hemorrhage and, in some cases, present with seizures. The diagnosis of AVMs is often made based on neuroimaging studies, and treatment may involve surgical intervention or embolization to prevent further hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man complained of inability to shut his left eye, difficulty in chewing food inside his mouth and weakness on the same side of his mouth with slight numbness on the left cheek. All these symptoms manifested two weeks prior, following an excisional biopsy of a left facial lump that proved to be a benign parotid tumor. On examination, there was an area of mild numbness on the left cheek. Examination of facial muscles revealed paralysis of facial muscles as a result of injury to facial nerve branches that must have happened during the biopsy. The patient was suggested intensive physiotherapy sessions and regular checkups to monitor the progress. Which among the following statements pertaining to the above case is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Numbness on the left cheek is due to injury of buccal branch of facial nerve

options.label: B
options.text: Facial nerve lies deep within the parotid gland

options.label: C
options.text: Buccinator prevents accumulation of food within vestibule of mouth

options.label: D
options.text: Orbicularis oculi is innervated solely by temporal branch of facial nerve

questions.correct_answer: B. Facial nerve lies deep within the parotid gland
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Facial nerve lies deep within the parotid gland.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A . Numbness on the left cheek is likely due to injury to the infraorbital nerve, which is a branch of the maxillary nerve (V2) of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), rather than the buccal branch of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). The buccal branch of the facial nerve primarily innervates the muscles of the cheek, and its injury typically results in weakness or paralysis of those muscles rather than numbness.
  • • Option A
  • • Option C . The buccinator muscle is primarily responsible for flattening the cheek during chewing and is involved in actions such as sucking and blowing. It helps in keeping the food against the teeth during chewing but does not prevent the accumulation of food within the vestibule of the mouth. The muscles of mastication, such as the masseter and temporalis muscles, are more involved in chewing and preventing food from spilling out of the mouth.
  • • Option C
  • • Option D . The orbicularis oculi muscle, responsible for closing the eyelids, is innervated by branches of the facial nerve, including the temporal, zygomatic, and buccal branches, not solely by the temporal branch. Injury to these branches can result in weakness or paralysis of the orbicularis oculi muscle, leading to difficulty in closing the eye, as seen in the presented case.
  • • Option D
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The facial nerve does indeed lie deep within the parotid gland. During surgery or biopsy of the parotid gland, there is a risk of damaging branches of the facial nerve, which can lead to facial weakness or paralysis, as seen in this case.
  • • The symptoms described in the case are consistent with injury to branches of the facial nerve during the excisional biopsy of the parotid tumor.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male prisoner, sentenced to death, underwent execution by judicial hanging. The execution was performed with a calculated drop length. Upon autopsy, the forensic expert observed a specific finding with no signs of struggle or defensive injuries. Considering the mechanism of death in judicial hangings and the autopsy findings, what is the most likely cause of death in this case?
questions.correct_answer: C. Fracture of upper cervical vertebra
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fracture of upper cervical vertebra

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In judicial hanging, the cause of death is predominantly due to the fracture of the upper cervical vertebrae, particularly the fracture-dislocation of the C2 vertebra (axis), often referred to as a "hangman's fracture." This type of hanging is designed to cause a rapid fracture-dislocation of the neck, resulting in immediate unconsciousness and rapid death, primarily through spinal cord injury and disruption of the brainstem functions.
  • • Other Options -
  • • Other Options -
  • • Option A. Airway occlusion : While this can occur in hangings, it is not the primary mechanism in judicial hanging, which aims for a quick fracture of the neck.
  • • Option A. Airway occlusion
  • • Option B. Vasovagal shock : This is a less likely primary cause of death in judicial hangings, as the mechanism is designed to be quick and efficient.
  • • Option B. Vasovagal shock
  • • Option D. Coma : Coma may result from the injury, but it is not the primary mechanism of death in judicial hanging.
  • • Option D. Coma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Judicial hanging typically results in death due to the fracture of the upper cervical vertebrae, leading to immediate unconsciousness and rapid death due to spinal cord injury and brainstem disruption.

questions.text: A 6-week-old boy is brought to the clinic because of fever. Urinalysis is positive for WBCs. Physical examination reveals the boy’s urethral opening to be displaced to the ventral (inferior) aspect of the penis. Which of the following is the embryologic cause of this congenital abnormality?

options.label: A
options.text: Abnormal expansion of the ureteric bud

options.label: C
options.text: Failure of the mesonephric (wolffian) duct to regress

questions.correct_answer: D. Incomplete fusion of urethral (urogenital) folds
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Incomplete fusion of urethral (urogenital) folds

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option D. Incomplete fusion of urethral (urogenital) folds : This is the correct answer. Hypospadias results from the incomplete fusion of the urethral folds, which are supposed to wrap around the penile urethra and fuse along the midline to form the spongy urethra. Incomplete fusion results in the urethral opening being located on the ventral side of the penis rather than at the tip.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Incomplete fusion of urethral (urogenital) folds
  • • Option A. Abnormal expansion of the ureteric bud : The ureteric bud is involved in the development of the ureters, renal pelvis, calyces, and collecting ducts of the kidneys. Abnormalities in the ureteric bud would lead to renal system malformations, not hypospadias.
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • Abnormal expansion of the ureteric bud
  • • Option B. Abnormal positioning of the genital tubercle : The genital tubercle is the precursor to the glans penis in males and the clitoris in females. While its positioning affects the development of these structures, abnormal positioning of the genital tubercle is not directly associated with hypospadias. Hypospadias is more related to the development and fusion of the urethral folds.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Abnormal positioning of the genital tubercle
  • • Option C. Failure of the mesonephric (Wolffian) duct to regress : The mesonephric ducts are precursors to certain male reproductive structures (e.g., the epididymis, vas deferens, seminal vesicles) in the presence of male hormones. Failure of these ducts to regress would not result in hypospadias but could lead to other genital abnormalities.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Failure of the mesonephric (Wolffian) duct to regress

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key learning point is to understand the embryological development of the male urethra and the causes of congenital abnormalities such as hypospadias. Specifically, it is important to recognize that hypospadias is caused by the incomplete fusion of the urethral folds, leading to an abnormally positioned urethral opening on the penis. Understanding the normal and abnormal processes of urethral development is crucial for diagnosing and managing congenital genitourinary abnormalities.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man has experienced lower abdominal pain for the past day. When examined in the emergency room, palpation of the abdomen reveals no masses, and bowel sounds are still present. He has pain most localized to the right lower quadrant, along with rebound tenderness. His total WBC count is elevated, with left shift. At laparoscopy, the specimen shown here is obtained. Which of the following is likely to be the most prominent microscopic finding in this specimen?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option B. Acute inflammation - The clinical picture is consistent with acute appendicitis, which is characterized by lower abdominal pain, particularly in the right lower quadrant, rebound tenderness, and an elevated WBC count with a left shift. These findings correlate with acute inflammation on a microscopic level, which would be the expected finding in a resected appendix.
  • • Option B. Acute inflammation
  • • Option A. Adenocarcinoma - This is a type of cancer that typically presents with a longer history of symptoms. The acute onset of pain, localized tenderness in the right lower quadrant, and elevated WBC count with left shift are not characteristic of adenocarcinoma, but rather indicate an acute process.
  • • Option A. Adenocarcinoma
  • • Option C. Chronic inflammation - Chronic inflammation would likely present with a longer duration of symptoms and would not typically present with such an acute onset of severe localized pain and systemic signs of acute infection such as a significant left shift in the WBC count.
  • • Option C. Chronic inflammation
  • • Option D. Coagulative necrosis - Coagulative necrosis is often seen in infarctions or areas of tissue death due to ischemia, not typically associated with acute appendicitis. The clinical presentation does not suggest ischemia as the primary process.
  • • Option D. Coagulative necrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The clinical presentation of acute, localized right lower quadrant pain with rebound tenderness, and laboratory findings of an elevated WBC count with left shift in a young adult is most consistent with acute inflammation , likely due to acute appendicitis, which is the expected microscopic finding in the specimen.
  • ➤ acute inflammation

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman presents with fatigue, a 4.5-kg (9.9-lb) weight gain over the past three months, cold intolerance, hair loss, and concentration problems. Physical examination is significant for dry, coarse skin and bradycardia. She states that she had some slight swelling of her lower neck several months ago, which resolved without treatment. Results of antithyroglobulin antibody and antinuclear antibody tests are negative, but a thyroid peroxidase antibody test is positive. For which other autoimmune diseases does this patient have an increased risk?

options.label: D
options.text: Type 1 diabetes mellitus and celiac disease

questions.correct_answer: D. Type 1 diabetes mellitus and celiac disease
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Type 1 diabetes mellitus and celiac disease

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option D. Type 1 diabetes mellitus and celiac disease : Both Type 1 diabetes mellitus, which involves autoimmune destruction of insulin-producing pancreatic beta cells, and celiac disease, an autoimmune response to dietary gluten affecting the small intestine, are associated with other autoimmune conditions, including autoimmune thyroid diseases. This option is also plausible and represents a common clustering of autoimmune conditions known as autoimmune polyglandular syndromes. Among the options, Type 1 diabetes mellitus and celiac disease best represents the cluster of autoimmune diseases commonly associated with autoimmune thyroid conditions such as Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Patients with one autoimmune disease, such as Hashimoto's thyroiditis, indeed have an increased risk of developing other autoimmune diseases, including Type 1 diabetes and celiac disease.
  • • Option D.
  • • Type 1 diabetes mellitus and celiac disease
  • • Type 1 diabetes mellitus and celiac disease
  • • Option A. Graves' disease and pernicious anemia : Graves' disease is an autoimmune condition leading to hyperthyroidism, not typically associated with Hashimoto's thyroiditis, which leads to hypothyroidism. Pernicious anemia, caused by autoantibodies against intrinsic factor or parietal cells leading to vitamin B12 deficiency, can be associated with autoimmune thyroid diseases. So, this option partially fits.
  • • Option A.
  • • Graves' disease and pernicious anemia
  • • Option B. Osteoarthritis and Addison's disease : Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease and is not autoimmune in nature. Addison's disease, an autoimmune destruction of the adrenal cortex leading to adrenal insufficiency, can be associated with other autoimmune conditions, including autoimmune thyroid diseases. So, this option partially fits as well.
  • • Option B.
  • • Osteoarthritis and Addison's disease
  • • Option C. Rheumatoid arthritis and vitiligo : Rheumatoid arthritis, an autoimmune disease affecting the joints, and vitiligo, an autoimmune condition causing loss of skin pigmentation, can both occur in individuals with other autoimmune conditions, including autoimmune thyroid diseases. This option is plausible.
  • • Option C.
  • • Rheumatoid arthritis and vitiligo

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key educational objective is to understand the concept of autoimmune polyglandular syndromes, where individuals with one autoimmune disease are at increased risk for developing other autoimmune conditions. Specifically, patients with autoimmune thyroid diseases like Hashimoto's thyroiditis are at increased risk for other autoimmune diseases, including Type 1 diabetes mellitus and celiac disease. Recognizing these associations is important for early diagnosis and management of these conditions.

questions.text: A mother brings her 3-year-old child with complaints of not growing well. On asking the history, the child had a history of low birth weight. She also had feeding difficulties and poor appetite. On examination, the child has a feature of prominent forehead, small jaw and narrow chin. On examination, she also had clinodactyly. The appearance of the child is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Russell-Silver syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Russell-Silver Syndrome is a genetic condition marked by unique facial features, such as a prominent forehead, small jaw, and narrow chin, along with intrauterine growth restriction and postnatal growth challenges, clinodactyly, and potential metabolic complications due to genetic alterations, specifically on chromosome 11p15 or maternal disomy of chromosome 7.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st Edition

  • ➤ Nelson 21 st Edition

questions.text: A patient with a history of repetitive strain injuries presents with persistent pain and limited joint mobility. Biopsy of the affected tissue reveals altered cellular architecture. Given the patient's symptoms and tissue findings, which of these intermediate filament proteins is potentially impacting tissue flexibility and function?

Ans. C) Vimentin

  • • Option A.
  • • Tubulin
  • • protein
  • • microtubules
  • • Option B. Actin is a protein that forms microfilaments, which are involved in cell motility and muscle contraction . While important for cellular movement, it is not the primary intermediate filament found in fibroblasts.
  • • Option B.
  • • Actin
  • • protein
  • • microfilaments,
  • • cell motility
  • • muscle contraction
  • • Option D. Myosin is a motor protein involved in muscle contraction and intracellular transport . It is not an intermediate filament protein and is not typically found in fibroblasts.
  • • Option D.
  • • Myosin
  • • motor protein
  • • muscle contraction
  • • intracellular transport

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand the role of intermediate filament proteins , with a focus on vimentin , in maintaining tissue flexibility and cellular architecture , particularly in fibroblasts .
