questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of asthma undergoes elective hernia repair under general anesthesia. Halfway through the procedure, the anesthesiologist notes a sudden increase in peak airway pressures. The patient’s breath sounds are diminished bilaterally, with audible wheezing. The capnograph is as shown below. The surgeon has been informed, and there have been no changes in the surgical field. What is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bronchospasm

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Circuit disconnection would lead to an abrupt loss of capnograph tracing and the absence of ETCO2.
  • • Option A. Circuit disconnection
  • • Option B. Pulmonary embolism may show a sudden decrease in ETCO2 due to impaired pulmonary perfusion, not the described capnograph changes.
  • • Option B. Pulmonary embolism
  • • Option D. Esophageal intubation results in the absence of CO2 on the capnograph after several breaths, as CO2 is not typically present in the stomach.
  • • Option D. Esophageal intubation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her sister after a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. The patient appears confused and is unable to answer questions. Her sister says that the patient has never had a seizure before and does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. The sister is unaware of any medical or psychiatric history but reports that sometimes the patient feels anxious and sad and has trouble sleeping. For the past 6 months, the patient has been taking medication, prescribed by her primary care doctor to help with these issues. The sister says that the patient had not taken any of the medication in 2 days, as they were on their way to a concert in another state. There is no family history of seizure disorder. Which of the following medications was this patient most likely taking?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Alprazolam

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option A: This patient had a first seizure after missing doses of her medication for 2 days. Of the medications listed, alprazolam, a short acting benzodiazepine, is the most likely to result in seizures following abrupt discontinuation. Symptoms of withdrawal from benzodiazepines with short half-livescan appear as early as 24 hours after cessation and include seizures, tremors, anxiety, perceptual disturbances, and psychosis. Although benzodiazepines are still commonly used in the treatment of insomnia and mixed anxiety and depression, their use can be problematic due to the potential for tolerance, dependence, and abuse. Benzodiazepines with shorter half-lives, such as alprazolam, have a greater risk of more severe withdrawal reactions; this contributes to the drug's reinforcing effects that increase its abuse potential.
  • • Option A:
  • • Option B: Seizures are potential dose-dependent side effects of the dopamine/norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor bupropion. These side effects are more likely to be seen in patients susceptible to seizures (e.g., epilepsy, electrolyte imbalances), with abrupt dosage increases or doses above the daily maximum. Seizures are not associated with their withdrawal.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option C: Mirtazapine is an alpha-2receptor antagonist antidepressant that is not associated with seizure following abrupt discontinuation.
  • • Option C:
  • • Option D: Lamotrigine is an anticonvulsant used in the treatment of bipolar disorder. Rapid discontinuation could result in/seizures in a patient with an underlying seizure disorder. However, this patient does not have a history of epilepsy.
  • • Option D:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Abrupt cessation of alprazolam, a short acting benzodiazepine, is associated with significant withdrawal symptoms, including risk for generalized seizures and confusion.

questions.text: A post-operative patient developed septicemia and was empirically started on combination chemotherapy by a new resident doctor. However, when the patient did not respond even after 10 days of antibiotics treatment, the review of the charts was done. It was found that that the resident doctor had started the combination of antibiotics which was mutually antagonistic in action. Which of the following is the most likely combination that was given?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ampicillin and chloramphenicol

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option C. Ampicillin and chloramphenicol:
  • • Option C. Ampicillin and chloramphenicol:
  • • Ampicillin is a penicillin antibiotic effective against Gram-positive and some Gram-negative bacteria. Chloramphenicol is a broad-spectrum antibiotic effective against a wide range of bacteria, both Gram-positive and Gram-negative. The combination of ampicillin and chloramphenicol is known to be antagonistic, as they interfere with each other's mechanism of action.
  • • Ampicillin is a penicillin antibiotic effective against Gram-positive and some Gram-negative bacteria.
  • • Chloramphenicol is a broad-spectrum antibiotic effective against a wide range of bacteria, both Gram-positive and Gram-negative.
  • • The combination of ampicillin and chloramphenicol is known to be antagonistic, as they interfere with each other's mechanism of action.
  • • Option A. Vancomycin and amikacin:
  • • Option A. Vancomycin and amikacin:
  • • Vancomycin is a glycopeptide antibiotic used to treat Gram-positive bacterial infections. Amikacin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic effective against various Gram-negative bacteria. These antibiotics target different types of bacteria, and there is no known antagonistic interaction between them.
  • • Vancomycin is a glycopeptide antibiotic used to treat Gram-positive bacterial infections.
  • • Amikacin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic effective against various Gram-negative bacteria.
  • • These antibiotics target different types of bacteria, and there is no known antagonistic interaction between them.
  • • Option B. Cephalexin and gentamicin:
  • • Option B. Cephalexin and gentamicin:
  • • Cephalexin is a cephalosporin antibiotic primarily used for Gram-positive bacterial infections. Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic effective against various Gram-negative bacteria. These antibiotics also target different types of bacteria, and there is no known antagonistic interaction between them.
  • • Cephalexin is a cephalosporin antibiotic primarily used for Gram-positive bacterial infections.
  • • Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic effective against various Gram-negative bacteria.
  • • These antibiotics also target different types of bacteria, and there is no known antagonistic interaction between them.
  • • Option D. Ciprofloxacin and piperacillin:
  • • Option D. Ciprofloxacin and piperacillin:
  • • Ciprofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic effective against a variety of Gram-negative and some Gram-positive bacteria. Piperacillin is a broad-spectrum penicillin antibiotic used for both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacterial infections. These antibiotics target different types of bacteria, and there is no known antagonistic interaction between them.
  • • Ciprofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic effective against a variety of Gram-negative and some Gram-positive bacteria.
  • • Piperacillin is a broad-spectrum penicillin antibiotic used for both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacterial infections.
  • • These antibiotics target different types of bacteria, and there is no known antagonistic interaction between them.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To highlight the importance of understanding the interactions between antibiotics when prescribing combination therapy. In this case, the combination of ampicillin and chloramphenicol was chosen, which is known to be antagonistic. It is crucial for healthcare professionals to be aware of potential drug interactions to ensure effective and safe treatment for patients.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is diagnosed with type I familial dyslipidemia. Recent laboratory studies show an elevated triglyceride level but normal LDL and HDL cholesterol levels. Which of the following explains the pathophysiology of this disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lipoprotein lipase deficiency

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option C : Lipoprotein lipase deficiency - This is the correct answer. Type I familial dyslipidemia, also known as familial chylomicronemia syndrome, is caused by a deficiency in lipoprotein lipase (LPL). LPL is an enzyme that plays a crucial role in the hydrolysis of triglycerides in chylomicrons and VLDL, allowing for their clearance from the bloodstream. Deficiency in LPL results in the accumulation of chylomicrons and extremely elevated triglyceride levels, which can lead to pancreatitis and other complications.
  • • Option C
  • • Lipoprotein lipase deficiency
  • • Option A : Apolipoprotein E deficiency - Apolipoprotein E (ApoE) is involved in lipid metabolism and is necessary for the binding and uptake of lipoproteins by receptors in various tissues. Deficiency of ApoE can result in impaired lipoprotein clearance, leading to elevated levels of cholesterol and triglycerides. However, it is not the primary cause of type I familial dyslipidemia.
  • • Option A
  • • Apolipoprotein E deficiency
  • • Option B : LDL cholesterol receptor deficiency - Familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) is characterized by a deficiency or dysfunction of LDL receptors, which are responsible for the uptake of LDL cholesterol from the bloodstream. FH leads to elevated LDL cholesterol levels and an increased risk of premature cardiovascular disease. It is a distinct condition from type I familial dyslipidemia.
  • • Option B
  • • LDL cholesterol receptor deficiency
  • • Option D : VLDL cholesterol clearance deficiency - This option is not the primary cause of type I familial dyslipidemia. While impaired VLDL clearance can contribute to elevated triglyceride levels, type I familial dyslipidemia is primarily associated with LPL deficiency.
  • • Option D
  • • VLDL cholesterol clearance deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type I familial dyslipidemia, or familial chylomicronemia syndrome, is characterized by a deficiency in lipoprotein lipase (LPL), leading to impaired clearance of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins like chylomicrons. Understanding the specific enzyme deficiencies associated with different lipid disorders is essential for accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Which of these is not a surgical modality for Senile entropion?

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above are used

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Anterior lamellar resection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To identify the different surgical modalities for the treatment of Senile entropion and understand why certain procedures are preferred over others.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother because he has had intermittent pain in the right hip during the past two weeks. The patient ambulates with difficulty. He has not had fever, chills, malaise, recent illness, or trauma to the hip. The patient is obese but otherwise healthy. On physical examination, vague pain in the groin is elicited on range of motion of the right hip. The most appropriate next step is x-ray studies to rule out which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Slipped capital femoral epiphysis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option C. Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis (SCFE) : SCFE is a condition where the ball at the head of the femur slips off the neck of the bone in a backward direction. This typically occurs in children during their growth spurt, and risk factors include obesity. It presents with hip, groin, thigh, or knee pain, and difficulty walking. Given the patient's age, obesity, and symptoms, SCFE is a likely possibility.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis (SCFE)
  • • Option A. Femoral Acetabular Impingement Syndrome : This condition involves an abnormal contact between the hip joint's ball and socket, leading to pain and limited range of motion. It's more common in young adults involved in high-level physical activity, and less likely in a pre-adolescent child with no history of athletic overuse.
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • Femoral Acetabular Impingement Syndrome
  • • Option B. Tear of the Labrum : The labrum is a ring of cartilage surrounding the hip socket. A tear can cause hip pain and stiffness, typically resulting from trauma, structural abnormalities, or repetitive motion activities. Labral tears are less common in children and are usually associated with specific injury or chronic repetitive activities.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Tear of the Labrum
  • • Option D. Septic Arthritis : This is an infection in the joint, causing severe pain, swelling, fever, and difficulty moving the joint. Given the absence of fever, chills, or malaise, septic arthritis is less likely, although it should not be completely dismissed without appropriate evaluation.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Septic Arthritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When evaluating a child with hip pain, particularly in the context of obesity and no recent trauma, SCFE should be a primary consideration. X-ray studies are crucial in the diagnosis of SCFE, which can have significant implications for the child's mobility and hip joint health if not treated promptly.

questions.text: A medical student presents to an infectious disease specialist complaining of abdominal distention and tenderness. The patient reports no recent changes in normal bowel habits. Physical examination shows hepatosplenomegaly. Bowel sounds are normal. On questioning, the patient reports that he travelled to Brazil several months ago to study tribal medical practices. He frequently went swimming in the Amazon River to wash himself. Several weeks after returning from his trip, he recalls having fever, diarrhea, weight loss, and “funny looking” stools. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this patient’s present symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Portal hypertension

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option D. Portal hypertension : This condition is an increase in the blood pressure within the portal venous system, commonly caused by cirrhosis of the liver. In the context of travel to an endemic area, the student's symptoms could be due to a chronic infection leading to liver damage and subsequent portal hypertension. One possible cause is schistosomiasis, a parasitic disease caused by trematode worms (Schistosoma species), which is endemic to regions including Brazil. Schistosomiasis can cause granulomatous reactions and fibrosis in the liver, leading to portal hypertension. The hepatosplenomegaly, abdominal distension, and the history of swimming in the Amazon River (where freshwater snails that host Schistosoma larvae are found) strongly suggest this diagnosis. Therefore, the most likely condition responsible for the patient's present symptoms, considering the travel history and clinical presentation, is Portal hypertension , likely secondary to schistosomiasis.
  • • Option D.
  • • Portal hypertension
  • • Portal hypertension
  • • Option A. Appendicitis : This condition typically presents with acute right lower quadrant abdominal pain, fever, and nausea. The chronic course and travel history described here do not support acute appendicitis as the cause of this patient's symptoms.
  • • Option A.
  • • Appendicitis
  • • Option B. Bowel obstruction : Bowel obstruction usually presents with vomiting, severe abdominal pain, and changes in bowel habits, such as inability to pass gas or stools. The student's normal bowel sounds and lack of changes in bowel habits make this diagnosis less likely.
  • • Option B.
  • • Bowel obstruction
  • • Option C. Enterocolitis : This is an inflammation of the digestive tract that can cause symptoms like diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever. While the student's initial symptoms upon returning from Brazil could suggest an acute enterocolitis, the current presentation with hepatosplenomegaly and abdominal distension points towards a more systemic condition.
  • • Option C.
  • • Enterocolitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to recognize the presentation and complications of schistosomiasis, particularly in travellers returning from endemic areas. Schistosomiasis can lead to chronic liver disease and portal hypertension due to the immune response to the parasite eggs lodged in the liver, causing granulomatous reactions and fibrosis. Understanding the link between travel history, exposure to freshwater in endemic areas, and systemic symptoms is crucial for diagnosing and managing imported parasitic diseases.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by his friends after they found him unconscious next to an empty bottle of aspirin. The label indicates the bottle originally contained 100 tablets of 325 mg each. The patient has a history of chronic back pain for which he has been self-medicating. On examination, he is tachypnoeic with a respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute, and his blood gas analysis reveals a mixed respiratory alkalosis and metabolic acidosis. The serum salicylate level confirms a significant overdose. The medical officer is considering the appropriate treatment modalities to enhance elimination of the salicylate from the patient's system. Which of the following is the most effective treatment modality for aspirin poisoning in this case?
questions.correct_answer: B. Alkaline Diuresis by sodium bicarbonate
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Alkaline Diuresis by sodium bicarbonate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • FORCED ALKALINE DIURESIS, achieving a urinary pH of 7.5 to 9 promotes, excretion of drugs that are weak acids, such as salicylates, barbiturates, chlorpropamide, methotrexate, lithium etc. By increasing the urinary pH, these drugs become more ionized and less likely to be reabsorbed in the renal tubules, leading to their increased excretion in the urine.
  • • Other options
  • • Other options
  • • Option A. N Acetyl cysteine is used to treat paracetamol overdose/ poisoning

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with a chronic history of loose stools and intermittent abdominal pain. She has no significant travel history or unusual dietary habits. questions.text: A 34-year-old woman has noted problems with writing for the past month. She has difficulty controlling her hand movements, and the writing is nearly illegible. On examination, she has decreased strength in her right upper extremity and decreased light touch sensation over her left lower extremity. She has no decrease in mentation, and there is no reported seizure activity. A lumbar puncture is performed, and the CSF contains elevated levels of IgG, some mononuclear cells, and oligoclonal bands on gel electrophoresis. Which of the following pathologic findings in the CNS is she most likely to have?

options.label: A
options.text: Periventricular lymphoid aggregates with cells marking with CD19

options.label: B
options.text: Perivascular lymphocytes with demyelinated axons in white matter

options.label: C
options.text: Increased neurofibrillary tangles and neuritic plaques in the neocortex

options.label: D
options.text: Loss of pigmented neurons in the substantia nigra

questions.correct_answer: B. Perivascular lymphocytes with demyelinated axons in white matter
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Perivascular lymphocytes with demyelinated axons in white matter

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option B. Perivascular lymphocytes with demyelinated axons in white matter:
  • • Option B. Perivascular lymphocytes with demyelinated axons in white matter:
  • • The presence of perivascular lymphocytes with demyelinated axons in the white matter is a characteristic finding in multiple sclerosis (MS), an autoimmune demyelinating disease of the central nervous system. The clinical presentation of motor and sensory deficits, along with elevated IgG in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), is consistent with MS.
  • • The presence of perivascular lymphocytes with demyelinated axons in the white matter is a characteristic finding in multiple sclerosis (MS), an autoimmune demyelinating disease of the central nervous system. The clinical presentation of motor and sensory deficits, along with elevated IgG in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), is consistent with MS.
  • • Option A. Periventricular lymphoid aggregates with cells marking with CD19:
  • • Option A. Periventricular lymphoid aggregates with cells marking with CD19:
  • • Periventricular lymphoid aggregates with CD19-positive cells typically suggest an inflammatory process involving B cells. This finding is not characteristic of the described clinical presentation.
  • • Periventricular lymphoid aggregates with CD19-positive cells typically suggest an inflammatory process involving B cells. This finding is not characteristic of the described clinical presentation.
  • • Option C. Increased neurofibrillary tangles and neuritic plaques in the neocortex:
  • • Option C. Increased neurofibrillary tangles and neuritic plaques in the neocortex:
  • • Increased neurofibrillary tangles and neuritic plaques are pathological features of Alzheimer's disease, which primarily affects cognition and memory. This pathology is not associated with the described clinical symptoms, including motor deficits.
  • • Increased neurofibrillary tangles and neuritic plaques are pathological features of Alzheimer's disease, which primarily affects cognition and memory. This pathology is not associated with the described clinical symptoms, including motor deficits.
  • • Option D. Loss of pigmented neurons in the substantia nigra:
  • • Option D. Loss of pigmented neurons in the substantia nigra:
  • • Loss of pigmented neurons in the substantia nigra is a hallmark of Parkinson's disease, a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by motor symptoms such as tremors and bradykinesia. However, this condition does not explain the presence of sensory deficits, decreased strength, and elevated IgG levels in the CSF.
  • • Loss of pigmented neurons in the substantia nigra is a hallmark of Parkinson's disease, a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by motor symptoms such as tremors and bradykinesia. However, this condition does not explain the presence of sensory deficits, decreased strength, and elevated IgG levels in the CSF.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune demyelinating disease of the central nervous system. Pathologically, it is characterized by the presence of perivascular lymphocytes, demyelinated axons, and oligoclonal bands in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). MS can present with a wide range of neurological symptoms, including motor and sensory deficits, and is typically diagnosed based on clinical findings and supporting evidence from CSF analysis and neuroimaging.

questions.text: A mother brings her 6-month-old son to the pediatrician. She has noticed that he seems “afraid of light” and after some Internet research, she is concerned that he might be an albino. Laboratory analysis reveals uroporphyrin in his urine. The child most likely has which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option C : Deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase - This condition is known as porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) . It is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase, leading to the accumulation of uroporphyrinogens. PCT can cause photosensitivity (sensitivity to sunlight) and skin blistering, but it is not related to albinism.
  • • Option C
  • • Deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase
  • • porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT)
  • • Option A : Deficiency of coproporphyrinogen oxidase - This condition is known as hereditary coproporphyria . It is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme coproporphyrinogen oxidase, leading to the accumulation of certain porphyrins. However, it does not typically cause photophobia (sensitivity to light) and is not directly related to albinism.
  • • Option A
  • • Deficiency of coproporphyrinogen oxidase
  • • hereditary coproporphyria
  • • Option B : Deficiency of porphobilinogen deaminase - This condition is known as acute intermittent porphyria . It results from a deficiency of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase and leads to the accumulation of porphyrin precursors. Again, this condition does not typically manifest as photophobia or albinism.
  • • Option B
  • • Deficiency of porphobilinogen deaminase
  • • acute
  • • intermittent porphyria
  • • Option D : Overexpression of porphobilinogen deaminase - This option does not describe a known medical condition.
  • • Option D
  • • Overexpression of porphobilinogen deaminase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ This question addresses a porphyria known as porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT), which is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase. PCT can result in photosensitivity and skin symptoms but is not related to albinism. Understanding the different types of porphyrias and their associated enzyme deficiencies is important in diagnosing and managing these rare genetic disorders.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man who is a health care worker presents to his physician with vague abdominal discomfort. A physical examination reveals a tender liver, palpable to 6cm below the costal margin and scleral icterus. His laboratory studies are significant for an aspartate aminotransferase activity of 200 U/L and an alanine aminotransferase activity of 450 U/L. CT of the abdomen shows a dominant solid nodule in the liver. The tumor marker most likely to be increased in this patient is also likely to be elevated in which of the following malignancies?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Yolk sac carcinoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option D. Yolk sac carcinoma : This is a type of non-seminomatous germ cell tumor that can occur in the testes or ovaries and in extragonadal locations. Yolk sac tumors are known to produce AFP, making this marker elevated in patients with this type of cancer. Given the information provided and the association of AFP with both hepatocellular carcinoma and yolk sac carcinoma, the correct answer is Yolk sac carcinoma .
  • • Option D.
  • • Yolk sac carcinoma
  • • Yolk sac carcinoma
  • • Option A. Choriocarcinoma : This is a type of gestational trophoblastic disease and can also occur as a non-gestational germ cell tumor. The key tumor marker for choriocarcinoma is human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), not AFP.
  • • Option A.
  • • Choriocarcinoma
  • • Option B. Colorectal carcinoma : The most commonly used tumor marker in colorectal carcinoma is carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA). AFP is not typically elevated in colorectal cancer.
  • • Option B.
  • • Colorectal carcinoma
  • • Option C. Prostatic carcinoma : Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is the tumor marker used in the screening and monitoring of prostatic carcinoma. AFP is not associated with prostate cancer.
  • • Option C.
  • • Prostatic carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand the association of tumor markers with specific types of cancer. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is a tumor marker that is elevated in hepatocellular carcinoma and can also be elevated in germ cell tumors, particularly yolk sac carcinoma. Recognizing the significance of tumor markers can aid in the diagnosis, monitoring, and treatment planning for patients with cancer.

questions.text: A 45-year-old ophthalmologist, Dr. Verma, is leading a public health initiative in a district with a population of 1 million people. He is particularly focused on assessing the visual health of the younger population to implement early interventions and improve overall community eye care. As part of his comprehensive study, he has meticulously gathered data and discovered that within the demographic under 16 years of age, which constitutes 30% of the total district population, there is a significant concern: the prevalence of blindness stands at 0.8 per 1,000 individuals. Given this scenario, Dr. Verma is now tasked with calculating the total number of individuals affected by blindness in this age group to better target his health initiatives. Which of the following numbers most accurately represents the total number of blind individuals in the under-16 age group within the district, based on Dr. Verma's findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 240

Explanation:

  • • Explanation –
  • • First, let's calculate the under-16 population: 30% of 10 lacs
  • • = 0.30 x 1,000,000 = 300,000
  • • Now, using the prevalence rate to calculate the number of blind individuals in this age group:
  • • Number of blind individuals = (Prevalence rate/1000) x Total under-16 population
  • • Number of blind individuals = (0.8/1000) x 300,000 = 240

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ PREVALENCE IS A PROPORTION (Prevalence IS NOT A RATIO): Numerator is a part of denominator and is always expressed in percentage. Prevalence describes the balance between incidence, mortality and recovery
  • ➤ PREVALENCE IS A PROPORTION (Prevalence IS NOT A RATIO): Numerator is a part of denominator and is always expressed in percentage.
  • ➤ Prevalence describes the balance between incidence, mortality and recovery

questions.text: A hospital administrator is trying to optimize the utilization of health services. He aims to strike a balance such that the hospital beds are neither over-utilized nor underutilized. This can be gauged through the bed turnover interval which measures the amount of time beds in a hospital are unoccupied until the next patient's admission following a patient's discharge. To achieve optimum utilization of health services in the hospital, the bed turnover interval should ideally be:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Slightly positive

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Bed turnover interval gives an indication of the bed occupancy status in a hospital. Slight positive values in bed turnover interval indicate optimum utilization of services. This means that there is just enough time between the discharge of one patient and the admission of the next, ensuring efficient use without under or overburdening the hospital resources.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Largely positive : This implies a longer period of bed vacancy, which indicates underutilization of services possibly due to an inefficient admission process or poor-quality medical care.
  • • Option B. Largely positive
  • • Option C. Slightly negative : This suggests that the hospital is at or above 100% occupancy, hinting at a scarcity of beds and potentially over-utilizing services.
  • • Option C. Slightly
  • • negative
  • • Option D. Largely negative : This would mean a significant over-utilization of beds, with potential overburdening of resources and even patient care quality being compromised.
  • • Option D. Largely negative

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Bed turn over interval : Amount of time beds at hospital are unoccupied until next patients’ admission following a patients’ discharge. Bed turn-over ratio is a type of heath care utilization rate. Slight positive values indicates optimum utilization of services.
  • ➤ Bed turn over interval

questions.text: Priya, a 28-year-old office worker, presented with irritation and redness of her left eye at a local clinic. She had no previous history of eye problems or immunizations. On examination, a greyish-white membrane was noted over the bulbar and palpebral conjunctiva, which bled upon peeling. What is the likely etiology?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Corynebacterium diphtheria

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Let's explain each option:
  • • Let's explain each option:
  • • Option A. Corynebacterium diphtheria : Corynebacterium diphtheria can cause a characteristic greyish-white membrane over the conjunctiva, known as diphtheritic conjunctivitis. However, this infection is rare in developed countries due to widespread vaccination against diphtheria.
  • • Option A. Corynebacterium diphtheria
  • • Option B. Moraxella lacunata : Moraxella lacunata is not a common cause of conjunctivitis characterized by a greyish-white membrane. It is more associated with bacterial conjunctivitis presenting with purulent discharge.
  • • Option B. Moraxella lacunata
  • • Option C. Moraxella axenfeld : Moraxella axenfeld is not a recognized pathogen in conjunctivitis. It is a rare species of bacteria, and its role in ocular infections is limited.
  • • Option C. Moraxella axenfeld
  • • Option D. Chlamydia trachomatis : Chlamydia trachomatis is a common cause of trachoma, which can present with a greyish-white membrane over the conjunctiva, known as trachomatous inflammation follicular (TF). It often occurs in areas with poor sanitation and is a common cause of blindness worldwide.
  • • Option D. Chlamydia trachomatis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Corynebacterium diphtheria can cause a characteristic greyish-white membrane over the conjunctiva.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presents to your clinic with a skin lesion on his arm. He reports that the area around the lesion has reduced sensation to touch. On examination, you also note a thickened ulnar nerve. A skin biopsy is taken which shows acid-fast bacilli. Hypopigmented patch with sensory loss Peripheral nerve thickening Peripheral nerve thickening with sensory loss Skin biopsy demonstrating bacilli

questions.text: A forensic expert is conducting an autopsy and observes a clot with a distinctive layered appearance, resembling chicken fat, within the blood vessels of the deceased. This finding is characteristic and indicative of a specific type of thrombus. What type of thrombus is associated with a 'chicken fat' appearance?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Postmortem thrombus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The 'chicken fat' appearance is typical of a postmortem thrombus, which is also known as a postmortem clot. These clots can form after the cessation of blood circulation and are often found during autopsies. They have a gelatinous and layered structure, which can be easily distinguished from antemortem thrombi that are firmer and attached to the vessel walls. Antemortem thrombi are formed due to pathophysiological processes while the person is still alive and typically indicate a thrombotic event such as a heart attack or stroke.
  • • Two types of Postmortem thrombus:
  • • Two types of Postmortem thrombus:
  • • Red currant jelly : Occurs if the blood clots rapidly. RBCs do not have time to settle down hence RBCs are distributed in whole clot and hence the clot is uniformly dark red
  • • Red currant jelly
  • • Chicken fat : Occurs if the clotting is gradual. RBCs settle down and two different layers are seen :
  • • Chicken fat
  • • two different layers are seen
  • • Upper layer : A pale layer of serum and fibrin
  • • Upper layer
  • • Lower layer : Red (like red current layer)
  • • Lower layer
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Antemortem thrombus is firmly adheres to the lining endothelium, with a pale, granular and transversely ridged surface because of alternating layers of platelets and fibrin.
  • • Option A. Antemortem thrombus
  • • Option C. Gunshot injury - Gunshot wounds are typically characterized by tissue damage, bullet paths, stippling, and soot deposition depending on the range and calibre of the weapon used. Does not lead to thrombus.
  • • Option C. Gunshot injury

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Appearances of thrombus:
  • ➤ Appearances of thrombus:

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl was brought to the family physician because of increasing lethargy for 5 days. She had a sore throat 15 days prior to the office visit. On physical examination, she has periorbital edema. Initial laboratory studies show a serum BUN of 25 mg/dL and creatinine 2.7 mg/dL. A microscopic urinalysis shows hematuria with dysmorphic RBC's. The light microscopic appearance of her renal biopsy shows hypercellularity with PMN's present. The electron microscopic appearance is shown. Which of the following additional laboratory test findings is most likely to be present in this girl?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option A. Elevated serum glucose:
  • • Option A. Elevated serum glucose:
  • • Elevated serum glucose levels are indicative of diabetes or hyperglycemia. However, there is no direct association between elevated serum glucose and the clinical presentation described, which includes periorbital edema, elevated BUN and creatinine, hematuria with dysmorphic RBCs, and a renal biopsy showing hypercellularity.
  • • Elevated serum glucose levels are indicative of diabetes or hyperglycemia. However, there is no direct association between elevated serum glucose and the clinical presentation described, which includes periorbital edema, elevated BUN and creatinine, hematuria with dysmorphic RBCs, and a renal biopsy showing hypercellularity.
  • • Option B. Antibody to double-stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA):
  • • Option B. Antibody to double-stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA):
  • • Anti-dsDNA antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). While SLE can present with renal involvement (lupus nephritis), it typically does not manifest with periorbital edema and elevated BUN and creatinine. Additionally, the electron microscopic appearance of the renal biopsy image is not consistent with lupus nephritis.
  • • Anti-dsDNA antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). While SLE can present with renal involvement (lupus nephritis), it typically does not manifest with periorbital edema and elevated BUN and creatinine. Additionally, the electron microscopic appearance of the renal biopsy image is not consistent with lupus nephritis.
  • • Option C. Elevated antistreptolysin O titer (ASO titer):
  • • Option
  • • C. Elevated antistreptolysin O titer (ASO titer):
  • • Elevated ASO titers are indicative of recent streptococcal infection, such as streptococcal pharyngitis (strep throat). The patient's history of sore throat and the presence of periorbital edema suggest a post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). This condition can lead to renal involvement, elevated BUN and creatinine, and hematuria with dysmorphic RBCs.
  • • Elevated ASO titers are indicative of recent streptococcal infection, such as streptococcal pharyngitis (strep throat). The patient's history of sore throat and the presence of periorbital edema suggest a post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). This condition can lead to renal involvement, elevated BUN and creatinine, and hematuria with dysmorphic RBCs.
  • • Option D. Antiglomerular basement membrane antibody (anti-GBM antibody):
  • • Option D. Antiglomerular basement membrane antibody (anti-GBM antibody):
  • • Anti-GBM antibodies are associated with anti-GBM antibody disease or Goodpasture syndrome. This condition primarily affects the lungs and kidneys, leading to glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage. While it can present with renal involvement, it typically does not cause periorbital edema.
  • • Anti-GBM antibodies are associated with anti-GBM antibody disease or Goodpasture syndrome. This condition primarily affects the lungs and kidneys, leading to glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage. While it can present with renal involvement, it typically does not cause periorbital edema.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is an immune-mediated glomerular disease that occurs following a streptococcal infection, such as streptococcal pharyngitis (strep throat) or impetigo. PSGN can lead to renal involvement, characterized by periorbital edema, elevated BUN and creatinine, hematuria with dysmorphic RBCs, and immune complex deposition in the glomeruli. Elevated antistreptolysin O (ASO) titers are a diagnostic marker for recent streptococcal infection in PSGN.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the interactions between human immune cells and pathogens. They are particularly interested in the complement receptor that binds C3d, an opsonization product. Which of the following receptors is primarily involved in this binding and is being investigated for its role in enhancing B cell responses?

Understanding the most common cause of ENNMR is crucial for developing effective prevention and management strategies in neonatal care. Given the complex interplay of various neonatal and maternal factors, which of the following is recognized as the primary cause of ENNMR?

questions.text: A baby boy dies several hours after birth. He was born with wrinkled skin, deformed limbs, and abnormal facies. The mother’s pregnancy was complicated by oligohydramnios. Which of the following embryologic processes most likely failed in this child?

options.label: B
options.text: Closure of the rostral neural tube

options.label: D
options.text: Migration of neural crest cells to the distal

questions.correct_answer: A. Development of the ureteric buds
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Development of the ureteric buds

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option A. Development of the ureteric buds : This is the correct answer. The ureteric buds are embryologic structures that give rise to the ureters, renal pelvis, calyces, and collecting ducts. Failure in the development of the ureteric buds can lead to renal agenesis (absence of one or both kidneys), which can cause oligohydramnios due to the lack of urine production by the fetus. The absence of amniotic fluid results in the compression of the fetus, leading to the physical anomalies described (Potter sequence).
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • Development of the ureteric buds
  • • Option B. Closure of the rostral neural tube : This process is important for the development of the brain and the skull. Failure in this process leads to neural tube defects such as anencephaly or encephaloceles, but would not directly result in the constellation of findings described in the scenario, particularly the oligohydramnios.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Closure of the rostral neural tube
  • • Option C. Formation of the tracheoesophageal septum : This process is crucial for the separation of the trachea and esophagus during embryonic development. Abnormalities in this process can lead to tracheoesophageal fistula or esophageal atresia. While these conditions are serious, they do not typically result in oligohydramnios or the described physical anomalies.
  • • Option
  • • C. Formation of the tracheoesophageal septum
  • • Option D. Migration of neural crest cells to the distal colon : This process is essential for the development of the enteric nervous system, particularly the ganglion cells in the colon. Failure of this migration leads to Hirschsprung's disease, characterized by a lack of ganglion cells in the distal colon, resulting in functional obstruction. Hirschsprung's disease would not cause oligohydramnios or the described physical anomalies.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Migration of neural crest cells to the distal colon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 69-year-old, slightly obese female presented with complaints of nausea, epigastric pain, vomiting, and tenderness, which she described as radiating or boring through her back for the past 48 hours. Her total cholesterol was elevated (greater than 200) on her last trip to the physician’s office. On physical examination, she is slightly tachycardic, BP is 100/60, and her temperature is 102. You noted that she was slightly jaundiced and has slight abdominal distension. She had diminished bowel sounds, and on palpation, tender but has no rebound pain and did not guard her abdomen. It was suspected that the patient was suffering from pancreatitis secondary to gallstones. Serum and urinary amylase, serum lipase, glucose, calcium levels, WBC, bilirubin – all of which were elevated except for the calcium, which was lowered. In addition, the patient’s CT demonstrated that some pancreatic tissue did not enhance with IV contrast, indicative of necrotizing pancreatitis. The patient was referred to a surgeon and taken to the O.R. for surgical debridement and placed on antibiotics. Blood supply to the pancreas is by all the following except:
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Left colic artery

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a 50 pack year history of smoking cigarettes has recently experienced an episode of hemoptysis along with his usual cough. On physical examination, he has no abnormal findings. A sputum for cytology on microscopic examination shows atypical cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and orange-pink cytoplasm. Laboratory studies show a serum calcium of 11.3 mg/dL, with phosphorus 2.1 mg/dL. Which of the following chest radiographic findings is this man most likely to have?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option D. Large hilar mass - This is the most likely finding associated with the patient's symptoms and laboratory results. A large hilar mass can cause hemoptysis and a cough. Hypercalcemia is suggestive of a paraneoplastic syndrome often seen in squamous cell carcinoma of the lung, which can present as a central hilar mass. The description of atypical cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and orange-pink cytoplasm is suggestive of malignancy, consistent with a diagnosis of lung cancer.
  • • Option D. Large hilar mass
  • • Option A. Carinal compression - Carinal compression is typically associated with symptoms such as stridor or signs of airway compression, which are not present in this patient. Moreover, carinal compression would not directly explain the hypercalcemia, which is a paraneoplastic syndrome often associated with malignancy.
  • • Option
  • • A. Carinal compression
  • • Option B. Pneumonia-like consolidation - While smokers are at risk for chronic bronchitis and pneumonia, the presence of atypical cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and the finding of hypercalcemia suggest a neoplastic process rather than an infectious one. Pneumonia-like consolidation would not typically present with the atypical cells seen in the sputum cytology.
  • • Option B. Pneumonia-like consolidation
  • • Option C. Peripheral nodule - While a history of smoking and the presence of a peripheral nodule could be consistent with a diagnosis of lung cancer, this does not typically present with hypercalcemia or the specific cytological findings seen in this case. Peripheral nodules are often asymptomatic and found incidentally on imaging.
  • • Option C. Peripheral nodule

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of hemoptysis, a significant smoking history, hypercalcemia, and cytological findings of atypical cells are highly suggestive of a large hilar mass , likely due to a lung malignancy such as squamous cell carcinoma, which can produce paraneoplastic hypercalcemia.
  • ➤ large hilar mass

questions.text: In the management of endometriosis, which of the following is the primary mechanism of action of danazol?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Inhibition of estrogen production

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Danazol is an isoxazole derivative of 17-alpha ethinyl testosterone. It is strictly anti-gonadotropin but acts as an androgen agonist. Mode of action : The mechanism of action is complex and includes the following : Acting on the hypothalamo-pituitary gonadal axis → depression of frequency of GnRH pulses → suppression of pituitary FSH and LH surge. There is, however, no change in the basal gonadotropin level while the estrogen levels are reduced. Reduces the liver synthesis of SHBG and as such, free testosterone is increased which in turn causes endometrial atrophy. Acts directly on the ovaries, inhibiting the enzymes responsible for steroidogenesis – reducing the estrogen level Binds with steroid receptors on the endometrium and also in the ectopic endometrial sites Immunologic effects of danazol include decrease in serum immunoglobulins, interleukin-1 and TNF production. This effect helps in the regression of endometriosis. The net result is production of an hypoestrogenic state Indications of use of Danazol: (Although it is now not very commonly used) Endometriosis Precocious puberty AUB PMS Symptomatic fibroid Benign fibrocystic disease of the breasts (mastalgia) Prior to hysteroscopic endometrial ablation, to make the endometrium thin Side effects of Danazol:

Reduces the liver synthesis of SHBG and as such, free testosterone is increased which in turn causes endometrial atrophy. Acts directly on the ovaries, inhibiting the enzymes responsible for steroidogenesis – reducing the estrogen level Binds with steroid receptors on the endometrium and also in the ectopic endometrial sites Immunologic effects of danazol include decrease in serum immunoglobulins, interleukin-1 and TNF production. This effect helps in the regression of endometriosis.

questions.text: As increased intracellular calcium is detrimental to the cell, calcium homeostasis is tightly regulated both across the cell membrane and within the cell via sequestration in the endoplasmic reticulum and mitochondria. In which of the following ways does increased intracellular calcium concentration cause the most cell damage?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Enzyme activation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option A: Enzyme activation - Increased intracellular calcium can lead to the activation of various enzymes within the cell. For example, calcium can activate proteases, which are enzymes that break down proteins, and lipases, which break down lipids. This can result in the degradation of cellular proteins and membranes, leading to cell damage and, in severe cases, cell death.
  • • Option A:
  • • Enzyme activation
  • • Option B : Free radical generation - While calcium itself doesn't directly generate free radicals, it can trigger processes that lead to the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS), which are free radicals. Excessive ROS can damage cellular components, including DNA, proteins, and lipids, contributing to cell injury and various diseases.
  • • Option B
  • • Free radical generation
  • • Option C : Increased membrane permeability - Elevated intracellular calcium levels can disrupt the integrity of cell membranes, including the plasma membrane and organelle membranes. This increased permeability can lead to the leakage of ions and other molecules, disrupting cellular functions and potentially causing cell death.
  • • Option C
  • • Increased membrane permeability
  • • Option D : Inhibition of oxidative phosphorylation - High intracellular calcium levels can interfere with mitochondrial function, including oxidative phosphorylation, which is critical for energy production in cells. Inhibition of this process can lead to decreased ATP production, affecting various cellular processes and potentially causing cell damage.
  • • Option D
  • • Inhibition of oxidative phosphorylation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The question addresses the detrimental effects of increased intracellular calcium concentration on cells. Calcium homeostasis is crucial for normal cell function, and disruptions in calcium regulation can lead to cell damage and various pathological conditions. Understanding the mechanisms by which elevated calcium levels can harm cells helps in grasping the importance of maintaining calcium homeostasis within cells to preserve their integrity and function.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol abuse presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset chest pain and dyspnea. He reports that the symptoms occurred after an episode of intense retching following a night of heavy drinking. A chest CT scan is performed and reveals the findings shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pneumomediastinum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option C. Pneumomediastinum : This is the correct diagnosis. Pneumomediastinum is the presence of air in the mediastinum, the central compartment in the thoracic cavity that contains the heart, major blood vessels, trachea, esophagus, and thymus. In this case, the sudden onset of chest pain and dyspnea following intense retching, combined with the physical examination findings of subcutaneous emphysema (air in the subcutaneous tissues of the neck and upper chest) and discomfort when swallowing, are classic signs. The chest CT showing air in the mediastinum without evidence of pneumothorax or pleural effusion further supports this diagnosis. Pneumomediastinum can occur due to alveolar rupture from increased intra-alveolar pressure (as might happen with violent retching), allowing air to dissect along the bronchovascular sheaths into the mediastinum.
  • • Option C. Pneumomediastinum
  • • Option A . Pneumothorax : This is the presence of air in the pleural space, which can cause the lung to collapse. While the symptoms of chest pain and dyspnea could be consistent with pneumothorax, the absence of pneumothorax on the CT scan rules out this diagnosis. Pneumothorax would typically show a visible rim of air outside the lung contour.
  • • Option A
  • • Pneumothorax
  • • Option B. Pneumoperitoneum : This is the presence of air within the peritoneal cavity, often due to gastrointestinal perforation. While abdominal pain and signs of peritonitis would be more common in pneumoperitoneum, the patient's symptoms are primarily respiratory and related to the thoracic cavity, and the CT scan findings do not indicate air in the abdominal cavity, making this diagnosis unlikely.
  • • Option B.
  • • Pneumoperitoneum
  • • Option D. Consolidation : This refers to the filling of the lung alveoli with fluid, pus, blood, cells, or other substances, leading to a region of lung tissue that appears solid on imaging. Common causes include pneumonia and pulmonary edema. The patient's symptoms and CT findings do not suggest consolidation, as there is no evidence of solid areas within the lung parenchyma on the scan.
  • • Option D.
  • • Consolidation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key educational objective here is to understand the clinical presentation and diagnostic approach to pneumomediastinum, particularly in the context of sudden-onset chest pain and dyspnea following an episode of intense retching. It is important to recognize the significance of subcutaneous emphysema and the specific CT findings that differentiate pneumomediastinum from other causes of acute chest pain, such as pneumothorax, pneumoperitoneum, and consolidation.

questions.text: A pediatrician is consulted for a 6-month-old infant presenting with acute gastroenteritis characterized by severe diarrhea and vomiting. The mother mentions that the child had recently started attending a local daycare. Stool analysis reveals the presence of a rotavirus. Which of the following enterotoxins is most likely responsible for the child's condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)  NSP4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In cases of rotavirus infection, NSP4 (Non-structural Protein 4) is known to act as an enterotoxin. It disrupts calcium homeostasis and leads to diarrhea. This scenario, featuring an infant with acute gastroenteritis and a confirmed rotavirus infection, points to NSP4 as the responsible enterotoxin.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. NSP6 - NSP6 is not recognized as an enterotoxin in rotavirus infections.
  • • Option
  • • B. NSP6
  • • Option C. VP3 - VP3 is not an enterotoxin associated with rotavirus.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Option D. VP7 - While VP7 is a structural protein of the rotavirus, it is not responsible for the enterotoxin activity leading to diarrhea.
  • • Option
  • • D. VP7

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The specific enterotoxin (NSP4) involved in rotavirus gastroenteritis, is a common cause of diarrhea in infants and young children.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1-c, 2-b, 3-d, 4-a

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Headache localized to occiput/vertex is often associated with sphenoid sinusitis. The sphenoid sinuses are located deep within the skull, behind the eyes. When they become inflamed, the pain can be referred to the back of the head, which is the occiput or the top of the head, known as the vertex. Thus, 1 matches with c (Sphenoid sinusitis). Pain over the bridge of the nose aggravated by movements of the eyeball is typically a symptom of ethmoid sinusitis. The ethmoid sinuses are located between the eyes and inflammation here can cause pain that is felt around the eyes and can be exacerbated by eye movements. Hence, 2 matches with b (Ethmoid sinusitis). Pain over the upper jaw aggravated by chewing is characteristic of maxillary sinusitis. The maxillary sinuses are located in the cheekbones, right beneath the eyes, and inflammation or infection can cause pain that is felt in the upper jaw, particularly when chewing. Therefore, 3 matches with d (Maxillary sinusitis). An office headache that starts in the morning and reduces by evening is often due to frontal sinusitis. The frontal sinuses are located above the eyes, in the forehead region. Pain and pressure from inflammation of the frontal sinuses can lead to a headache that is more pronounced in the morning and improves as the day progresses. Thus, 4 matches with a (Frontal sinusitis).
  • • Headache localized to occiput/vertex is often associated with sphenoid sinusitis. The sphenoid sinuses are located deep within the skull, behind the eyes. When they become inflamed, the pain can be referred to the back of the head, which is the occiput or the top of the head, known as the vertex. Thus, 1 matches with c (Sphenoid sinusitis).
  • • Headache localized to occiput/vertex
  • • Pain over the bridge of the nose aggravated by movements of the eyeball is typically a symptom of ethmoid sinusitis. The ethmoid sinuses are located between the eyes and inflammation here can cause pain that is felt around the eyes and can be exacerbated by eye movements. Hence, 2 matches with b (Ethmoid sinusitis).
  • • Pain over the bridge of the nose aggravated by movements of the eyeball
  • • Pain over the upper jaw aggravated by chewing is characteristic of maxillary sinusitis. The maxillary sinuses are located in the cheekbones, right beneath the eyes, and inflammation or infection can cause pain that is felt in the upper jaw, particularly when chewing. Therefore, 3 matches with d (Maxillary sinusitis).
  • • Pain over the upper jaw aggravated by chewing
  • • An office headache that starts in the morning and reduces by evening is often due to frontal sinusitis. The frontal sinuses are located above the eyes, in the forehead region. Pain and pressure from inflammation of the frontal sinuses can lead to a headache that is more pronounced in the morning and improves as the day progresses. Thus, 4 matches with a (Frontal sinusitis).
  • • office headache that starts in the morning and reduces by evening

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To identify the characteristic pain patterns associated with inflammation of different sinus areas, which can aid in the clinical diagnosis of sinusitis.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the office due to weight gain and low self-confidence. She says, "I've always had trouble with my weight and mood swings. I've gained 11 pounds [5 kg] in the last 2 years and feel horrible about myself. I go through this cycle in which I feel good, stick to a diet, and exercise for a couple of weeks, but then my mood gets really down. I start eating junk food and feel bloated until I get my period.” The patient is also upset about a recent fight with her best friend, saying "I blame myself because I am much more irritable before my period, and I lashed out at her for no reason. The following week I felt much better, but the damage was done." The patient has struggled with moodiness and being overweight for most of her adult life. She says, "I hate when I feel this way because, generally, I'm a pretty upbeat person.” Physical examination and laboratory evaluation are unremarkable. BMI is 29kg/m². Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Premenstrual dysphoric disorder

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option B: This patient's cyclical pattern of overeating, mood swings, and irritability, which worsen prior to menstruation and resolve for a few weeks at a time, is suggestive of premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD).PMDD, a severe variant of premenstrual syndrome (PMS), is characterized by prominent mood symptoms, including sadness, mood swings, anger, anxiety, irritability, and decreased interest, as well as fatigue, changes in appetite, and physical discomfort (eg, bloating, breast tenderness). These mood symptoms decrease in intensity or resolve completely after menstruation.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option A: Bulimia nervosa is characterized by episodes of excessive, uncontrollable eating within a specified period (e.g., 1-2 hr) that occur at least once a week for 3 months. In bulimia nervosa, this is accompanied by compensatory behaviors such as fasting, laxative abuse, or excessive exercising. Compared with patients with these eating disorders, this patient describes more cyclical pattern of overeating, together with mood lability and irritability, finding consistent with PMDD.
  • • Option A:
  • • Option B: Although irritability can be a symptom of hypomania, as seen in cyclothymic disorder, this patient does not have a history of other hypomanic symptoms (e.g., increased energy, decreased need for sleep, pressured speech, grandiosity), which is required to diagnose these disorders.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option C: Mood changes in the premenstrual phase are common, requiring differentiation of PMS and PMDD from premenstrual worsening of another medical or psychiatric condition. For example, patients with persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia), a chronic form of depression, may describe premenstrual exacerbation of depressive symptoms. However, careful history-taking in such a patient shows that depressive symptoms are present at other times during the menstrual cycle, unlike in this patient, who has 2 weeks of feeling good before the mood changes occur. The accurate diagnosis of PMDD requires prospective daily ratings for ≥2 cycles demonstrating a symptom-free period in the follicular phase.
  • • Option C:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Premenstrual dysphoric disorder is characterized by cyclical mood swings, irritability, appetite changes, and physical discomfort that resolve after menses. It is not diagnosed when premenstrual mood symptoms represent an exacerbation of an underlying disorder in which the symptoms are not limited to the premenstrual phase.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man complains of pain in his left thigh for 3 months. On physical examination, his thigh is increased in size, compared to the right. A plain film radiograph reveals the presence of a 15 cm solid mass that does not appear to arise from bone, but it does have infiltrative margins. A biopsy of this mass is taken, and on microscopic examination, the mass is composed of highly pleomorphic spindle cells. Which of the following immunohistochemical markers is most likely to be demonstrated in the cells of this mass?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vimentin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option D. Vimentin:
  • • Option D. Vimentin:
  • • Vimentin is an intermediate filament protein and is often used as an immunohistochemical marker to identify mesenchymal cells, including spindle cells. Spindle cell tumors, such as sarcomas, often express vimentin.
  • • Vimentin is an intermediate filament protein and is often used as an immunohistochemical marker to identify mesenchymal cells, including spindle cells. Spindle cell tumors, such as sarcomas, often express vimentin.
  • • Option A. Factor VIII:
  • • Option A. Factor VIII:
  • • Factor VIII is not an immunohistochemical marker used to identify spindle cell tumors. It is a coagulation factor.
  • • Factor VIII is not an immunohistochemical marker used to identify spindle cell tumors. It is a coagulation factor.
  • • Option B. Cytokeratin:
  • • Option B. Cytokeratin:
  • • Cytokeratin is an intermediate filament protein commonly used as an immunohistochemical marker to identify epithelial cells. It is not typically expressed in spindle cell tumors.
  • • Cytokeratin is an intermediate filament protein commonly used as an immunohistochemical marker to identify epithelial cells. It is not typically expressed in spindle cell tumors.
  • • Option C. Alpha fetoprotein:
  • • Option C. Alpha fetoprotein:
  • • Alpha fetoprotein is a tumor marker used in the diagnosis of certain types of tumors, particularly hepatocellular carcinoma and germ cell tumors. It is not associated with spindle cell tumors.
  • • Alpha fetoprotein is a tumor marker used in the diagnosis of certain types of tumors, particularly hepatocellular carcinoma and germ cell tumors. It is not associated with spindle cell tumors.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Spindle cell tumors are composed of elongated, spindle-shaped cells, and they can arise from various tissues. Immunohistochemical markers like vimentin are commonly used to help identify the mesenchymal origin of these tumors and differentiate them from other types of tumors.
  • ➤ Spindle cell tumors are composed of elongated, spindle-shaped cells, and they can arise from various tissues. Immunohistochemical markers like vimentin are commonly used to help identify the mesenchymal origin of these tumors and differentiate them from other types of tumors.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man has had back pain for 6 months. He recently developed a cough productive of yellowish sputum. On physical examination, he has no lymphadenopathy or splenomegaly. His temperature is 37.8°C. A radiograph of the spine reveals several 1 to 2 cm lytic lesions of the vertebral bodies. His serum urea nitrogen is 28 mg/dL and creatinine 3.0 mg/dL. A sputum culture grows Streptococcus pneumoniae . A bone marrow biopsy is performed, and the marrow smear is shown here. Which of the following laboratory test findings is most likely to be present in this man?

options.label: B
options.text: Tear drop cells in peripheral blood

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option D. Hypergammaglobulinemia - This condition is characterized by increased levels of immunoglobulins and is often associated with plasma cell dyscrasias, like multiple myeloma, which this patient's presentation suggests. The back pain, lytic bone lesions, renal insufficiency (as evidenced by the elevated creatinine), and a bone marrow biopsy showing atypical plasma cells strongly point towards multiple myeloma.
  • • Option D. Hypergammaglobulinemia
  • • Option A. Markedly elevated D-dimer - D-dimer is a fibrin degradation product present in the blood after a blood clot is degraded by fibrinolysis. It is typically elevated in conditions such as deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, or disseminated intravascular coagulation. This patient's presentation is not suggestive of these conditions.
  • • Option A. Markedly elevated D-dimer
  • • Option B. Tear drop cells in peripheral blood - Tear drop cells, or dacryocytes, are often associated with myelofibrosis and other myeloproliferative disorders. While bone marrow abnormalities are present, the symptoms and radiographic findings of lytic lesions are more suggestive of a plasma cell disorder.
  • • Option B. Tear drop cells in peripheral blood
  • • Option C. Decreased leukocyte alkaline phosphatase - This finding is typically associated with chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), which does not fit the clinical picture or the marrow findings described in the stem. CML usually presents with an elevated white blood cell count and often with splenomegaly.
  • • Option C. Decreased leukocyte alkaline phosphatase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The patient's symptoms of chronic back pain, radiographic evidence of lytic bone lesions, renal insufficiency, and a marrow smear suggestive of plasma cell proliferation are most consistent with hypergammaglobulinemia , likely secondary to multiple myeloma.
  • ➤ hypergammaglobulinemia

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of unilateral nasal obstruction, intermittent epistaxis, and a noticeable mass in the neck. On examination, a neck mass is palpable on the left side, and nasopharyngoscopy reveals a mass in the nasopharynx. Biopsy confirms the diagnosis of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Given the location of the primary tumor, which anatomical site in the nasopharynx is the most common origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Fossa of Rosenmüller

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. The Eustachian tube orifice is an important anatomical landmark in the nasopharynx but is not the most common site for the origin of NPC.
  • • Option A. The Eustachian tube orifice
  • • Option C. The nasopharyngeal roof , or the superior wall of the nasopharynx, is less commonly involved in NPC compared to the fossa of Rosenmüller.
  • • Option C. The nasopharyngeal roof
  • • Option D. The posterior nasopharyngeal wall is another potential site for NPC but is less frequently involved compared to the fossa of Rosenmüller.
  • • Option D. The posterior nasopharyngeal wall

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To identify the fossa of Rosenmüller as the most common site for the origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman has been complaining of chronic constipation for several months. She has been taking a laxative regularly for relief. She underwent colonoscopy which reveals the presence of dark black discoloration of colon (melanosis coli). Which of the following medications is most likely causing this discoloration of the colon?

Ans. B) Senna

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option B. Senna.
  • • Option B. Senna.
  • • Senna is a stimulant laxative known to cause melanosis coli. Senna is a stimulant laxative used to treat constipation. Prolonged and excessive use of senna can lead to melanosis coli, a benign condition characterized by dark discoloration of the colon.
  • • Senna is a stimulant laxative known to cause melanosis coli.

  • • stimulant laxative
  • • Senna is a stimulant laxative used to treat constipation.
  • • Prolonged and excessive use of senna can lead to melanosis coli, a benign condition characterized by dark discoloration of the colon.
  • • Option A. Liquid paraffin.
  • • Option A. Liquid paraffin.
  • • Liquid paraffin is a lubricant laxative that is not typically associated with melanosis coli . Liquid paraffin is a mineral oil laxative used to relieve constipation. It lubricates the stool and intestinal walls to ease passage.
  • • Liquid paraffin is a lubricant laxative that is not typically associated with melanosis coli .
  • • lubricant laxative
  • • not typically associated with melanosis coli
  • • Liquid paraffin is a mineral oil laxative used to relieve constipation.
  • • It lubricates the stool and intestinal walls to ease passage.
  • • Option C. Bisacodyl.
  • • Option C. Bisacodyl.
  • • Bisacodyl is another stimulant laxative known to cause melanosis coli. Bisacodyl is used for short-term relief of constipation. Similar to senna, prolonged use can result in melanosis coli.
  • • Bisacodyl is another stimulant laxative known to cause melanosis coli.
  • • Bisacodyl
  • • stimulant laxative
  • • Bisacodyl is used for short-term relief of constipation.
  • • Similar to senna, prolonged use can result in melanosis coli.
  • • Option D. Psyllium.
  • • Option D. Psyllium.
  • • Psyllium is a bulk-forming laxative and is not associated with melanosis coli . Psyllium is a plant-based fibre supplement used to promote regular bowel movements by adding bulk to the stool.
  • • Psyllium is a bulk-forming laxative and is not associated with melanosis coli .
  • • Psyllium
  • • bulk-forming laxative
  • • not associated with melanosis coli
  • • Psyllium is a plant-based fibre supplement used to promote regular bowel movements by adding bulk to the stool.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Melanosis coli is a benign and reversible condition of the colon characterized by dark discoloration. It is often associated with the chronic and prolonged use of certain laxatives, particularly stimulant laxatives like senna and bisacodyl. Healthcare providers should be aware of this condition when evaluating patients with chronic constipation who have a history of laxative use.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a history of large-bowel obstruction is diagnosed with colon cancer and undergoes resection of his colon. At check-up, he feels well except that over the past three weeks, he has had significant swelling in his legs. Physical examination reveals 2+ pitting edema and a blood pressure of 155/94 mmHg. Urinalysis shows 4+ protein with no RBCs or casts. Which of the following would most likely be present on a kidney biopsy from this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: A spike-and-dome pattern of deposition on electron microscopy

options.label: B
options.text: A tram-track pattern on light microscopy

options.label: C
options.text: Lumpy subepithelial deposits on electron microscopy

options.label: D
options.text: Nonlinear mesangial staining with IgA immunofluorescence

questions.correct_answer: A. A spike-and-dome pattern of deposition on electron microscopy
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A spike-and-dome pattern of deposition on electron microscopy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option A. A spike-and-dome pattern of deposition on electron microscopy : This is characteristic of membranous nephropathy. In this condition, subepithelial immune deposits lead to the formation of "spikes" on the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) when viewed with silver stain on light microscopy, and the "dome" represents the immune complex deposits seen on electron microscopy. This finding is consistent with the nephrotic syndrome in the context of the patient's colon cancer.
  • • Option A.
  • • A spike-and-dome pattern of deposition on electron microscopy
  • • Option B. A tram-track pattern on light microscopy : This pattern is typical of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN), which presents with mesangial proliferation and double contouring of the GBM. MPGN is more commonly associated with nephritic syndrome, complement disorders, or chronic infections and is less likely in this case.
  • • Option B.
  • • A tram-track pattern on light microscopy
  • • Option C. Lumpy subepithelial deposits on electron microscopy : Lumpy deposits are more commonly seen in post-infectious glomerulonephritis, which typically presents as an acute nephritic syndrome following a streptococcal infection, not a nephrotic syndrome in the context of malignancy.
  • • Option C.
  • • Lumpy subepithelial deposits on electron microscopy
  • • Option D. Nonlinear mesangial staining with IgA immunofluorescence : This finding would be indicative of IgA nephropathy (Berger's disease), which primarily presents with episodic hematuria, often following respiratory or gastrointestinal infections, and is not typically associated with nephrotic syndrome or secondary to malignancies.
  • • Option D.
  • • Nonlinear mesangial staining with IgA immunofluorescence

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To recognize the association between nephrotic syndrome and secondary causes, such as malignancy, and to understand the characteristic biopsy findings in membranous nephropathy, including the spike-and-dome pattern on electron microscopy. Identifying the underlying cause of nephrotic syndrome is crucial for appropriate management and treatment.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of chronic constipation and gastroparesis is seeking medical attention. The physician plans to initiate prokinetic therapy to alleviate the gastrointestinal motility issues. During the consultation, the patient inquires about the different classes of prokinetic drugs and their mechanisms of action. Which of the following drugs should the physician explain is NOT classified as a prokinetic drug?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Diphenoxymethane

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option D: Diphenoxymethane is not a prokinetic drug. It is the active metabolite of diphenoxylate. It slows the motility of the intestinal tract by binding to the mu-opioid receptors in the intestinal wall, which results in an increase in intestinal transit time and a decrease in fluid secretion.
  • • Option D:
  • • Option A: 5-HT4 agonists like mosapride are prokinetic drugs that act on the 5HT4 receptors in the GI tract to stimulate peristalsis and increase gastric emptying.
  • • Option A:
  • • Option B: D2 blockers such as metoclopramide and domperidone are commonly used as prokinetic drugs due to their ability to increase gastrointestinal motility.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option C: Macrolides are a group of antibiotics that have been shown to have prokinetic effects. They act by binding to motilin receptors in the gut and stimulating gastric motility.
  • • Option C:

The anesthesiologist decides to use neuromuscular monitoring to assess the depth of neuromuscular blockade to ensure adequate muscle relaxation throughout the procedure. As the surgical procedure comes to an end, the anesthesiologist prepares to reverse the neuromuscular blockade. He places electrodes and monitors the muscle group that will give the best indication of recovery from neuromuscular blockade. Which muscle group is the anesthesiologist most likely monitoring in this patient?

  • • muscle

questions.text: Identify the instrument in the picture below.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Indirect laryngoscopy mirror

It is a small, round mirror attached to a long handle. The mirror is warmed and placed at the back of the throat to visualize the larynx.
