questions.text: A 57-year-old woman has had dyspnea worsening for the past 10 years. On examination, crackles are ausculated over both lungs. Spirometry is performed and reveals a normal FEV1/FVC ratio with decreased FVC. Her total lung capacity is decreased. The DLCO (Diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide) is decreased. The representative gross appearance of her lung is shown here. Which of the following underlying conditions is she most likely to have?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option A. ANCA-associated granulomatous vasculitis:
  • • Option
  • • A. ANCA-associated granulomatous vasculitis:
  • • ANCA-associated vasculitis, such as granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), can affect the lungs and lead to pulmonary manifestations. However, the representative gross appearance of the lung shown does not specifically align with granulomatous vasculitis. This condition typically presents with pulmonary nodules and cavities.
  • • ANCA-associated vasculitis, such as granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), can affect the lungs and lead to pulmonary manifestations. However, the representative gross appearance of the lung shown does not specifically align with granulomatous vasculitis. This condition typically presents with pulmonary nodules and cavities.
  • • Option B. Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency:
  • • Option B. Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency:
  • • Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency is a genetic disorder that can lead to emphysema, particularly in individuals who are homozygous for the Z allele. Emphysema is characterized by the destruction of lung tissue and can lead to decreased lung function, as seen in this patient. The decreased DLCO is also consistent with emphysema.
  • • Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency is a genetic disorder that can lead to emphysema, particularly in individuals who are homozygous for the Z allele. Emphysema is characterized by the destruction of lung tissue and can lead to decreased lung function, as seen in this patient. The decreased DLCO is also consistent with emphysema.
  • • Option C. Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS):
  • • Option C. Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS):
  • • AIDS is associated with various opportunistic infections and malignancies, but it does not typically present with the specific lung findings seen in this patient, such as decreased total lung capacity and DLCO.
  • • AIDS is associated with various opportunistic infections and malignancies, but it does not typically present with the specific lung findings seen in this patient, such as decreased total lung capacity and DLCO.
  • • Option D. Diffuse scleroderma:
  • • Option D. Diffuse scleroderma:
  • • Diffuse systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) can lead to pulmonary fibrosis, which can result in restrictive lung disease with decreased lung volumes, including total lung capacity. The decreased DLCO is also consistent with scleroderma-associated lung disease.
  • • Diffuse systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) can lead to pulmonary fibrosis, which can result in restrictive lung disease with decreased lung volumes, including total lung capacity. The decreased DLCO is also consistent with scleroderma-associated lung disease.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diffuse systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) is an autoimmune connective tissue disorder characterized by fibrosis of the skin and internal organs. Pulmonary involvement in diffuse scleroderma can lead to restrictive lung disease, decreased lung volumes (e.g., total lung capacity), and decreased diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO). Fibrosis of the lungs is a common manifestation of this condition, which can result in dyspnea and crackles on lung auscultation.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child in a rural tropical community presents with multiple painless skin ulcers and periostitis. Which organism is the primary cause of these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)  Treponema pertenue

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Treponema pertenue is the causative agent of Yaws, a nonvenereal infection that primarily affects skin and bone.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Treponema pallidum is the causative agent of syphilis, a sexually transmitted infection.
  • • Option
  • • B. Treponema pallidum
  • • Option C. Treponema carateum causes Pinta, a skin disease that does not involve bone.
  • • Option
  • • C. Treponema carateum
  • • Option D. Haemophilus ducreyi causes Chancroid, a sexually transmitted infection characterized by painful genital ulcers.
  • • Option
  • • D. Haemophilus ducreyi

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Yaws, a treponemal infection caused by Treponema pertenue, which presents with painless skin ulcers and bone pain in children from tropical areas.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man comes to the clinic with a swollen, sausage-like left middle finger along with diffuse joint swelling of his left hand and right foot over the past three days. The patient also has scaly plaques with well-defined borders along the skin just distal to both elbows. His uric acid level is within normal limits. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Negatively birefringent crystals in joint fluid

options.label: D
options.text: Weakly positively birefringent crystals in joint fluid

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option B. Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) : This is the correct answer. An elevated ESR is a nonspecific marker of inflammation and can be seen in various inflammatory conditions, including psoriatic arthritis. ESR may be elevated in PsA due to systemic inflammation. Given the description of the patient's symptoms and the presence of psoriatic skin lesions, the most likely finding in this patient would be Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) , reflecting the systemic inflammation associated with psoriatic arthritis.
  • • Option B.
  • • Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
  • • Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
  • • Option A. Antigliadin antibodies : These antibodies are associated with celiac disease, an autoimmune disorder triggered by the ingestion of gluten in genetically susceptible individuals. There is no direct link between antigliadin antibodies and psoriatic arthritis.
  • • Option A.
  • • Antigliadin antibodies
  • • Option C. Negatively birefringent crystals in joint fluid : These crystals are characteristic of gout, which is caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals within the joint. Gout typically presents with acute, painful joint inflammation but does not cause the skin manifestations seen in psoriasis.
  • • Option C.
  • • Negatively birefringent crystals in joint fluid
  • • Option D. Weakly positively birefringent crystals in joint fluid : These crystals are associated with pseudogout, caused by the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD) crystals in the joint. Like gout, pseudogout presents with joint inflammation but does not include psoriatic skin lesions.
  • • Option D. Weakly positively birefringent crystals in joint fluid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To recognize the clinical features of psoriatic arthritis, including joint inflammation and psoriatic skin lesions, and understand the associated laboratory findings. An elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is a common finding in psoriatic arthritis due to systemic inflammation, and recognizing this can aid in the diagnosis and management of the condition.

questions.text: A 70 kg young athlete was planned for surgery. During anaesthesia, vecuronium was not available, so repeated doses of succinylcholine was given intermittently up to 640 mg. During recovery, patient was not able to spontaneously respire and move limbs. What is the cause?

options.label: C
options.text: Muscle weakness due to repeated fasciculations

questions.explanation: Ans. B) Phase II blockade

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents to his pediatrician with skin lesions all over his body. For several years, he has been very sensitive to sunlight. Neither the boy’s parents nor his siblings have the same skin lesions or sun sensitivity. Biopsies of several of the boy’s lesions reveal squamous cell carcinoma. Which mutation would one expect to see in this patient’s DNA?

options.label: C
options.text: Non-sense mutation in the middle of the gene

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Thymidine dimers

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option D : Thymidine dimers - Thymidine dimers are DNA lesions caused by ultraviolet (UV) radiation exposure, such as sunlight. UV radiation can induce the formation of covalent bonds between adjacent thymidine bases, disrupting the normal DNA structure. Thymidine dimers are strongly associated with skin cancer, particularly squamous cell carcinoma, in individuals with sensitivity to sunlight (photosensitivity).
  • • Option D
  • • Thymidine dimers
  • • Option A : Methylation of the gene - Methylation refers to the addition of a methyl group to DNA, which can result in gene silencing. While abnormal DNA methylation can play a role in cancer development, it is not a specific mutation within a gene.
  • • Option A
  • • Methylation of the gene
  • • Option B : Mis-sense mutation in the gene - A missense mutation is a type of point mutation where a single nucleotide change in the DNA sequence leads to the substitution of one amino acid with another in the resulting protein. This type of mutation can potentially lead to altered protein function and is associated with various genetic disorders, including some that can increase the risk of cancer.
  • • Option B
  • • Mis-sense mutation in the gene
  • • Option C : Non-sense mutation in the middle of the gene - A nonsense mutation is a type of point mutation where a premature stop codon is introduced in the DNA sequence. This results in the premature termination of protein synthesis, leading to a non-functional or truncated protein. Nonsense mutations can have significant consequences for gene function and are associated with various genetic disorders.
  • • Option C
  • • Non-sense mutation in the middle of the gene

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ This question highlights the link between exposure to UV radiation (e.g., from sunlight) and the formation of thymidine dimers in DNA. Thymidine dimers are a specific type of DNA damage that can lead to mutations in critical genes, ultimately increasing the risk of skin cancer, particularly squamous cell carcinoma. Understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying skin cancer development is crucial for diagnosis and prevention.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with a long history of poorly controlled diabetes mellitus and chronic renal failure is admitted to the hospital for treatment of cellulitis. Two days into her hospital stay, she complains of chest pain that is relieved when she leans forward. An ECG shows diffuse ST segment elevations with PR depressions; her echocardiogram is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment at this time?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dialysis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option A. Cardiac catheterization : Still not indicated, as the clinical picture is not suggestive of acute coronary syndrome, and the primary issue appears to be related to the patient's renal failure.
  • • Option A.
  • • Cardiac catheterization
  • • Option B. Dialysis : The scenario is pointing towards uremic pericarditis, a specific type of pericarditis associated with advanced renal failure or uremia. In patients with chronic renal failure, particularly those with inadequately treated uremia, the accumulation of uremic toxins can lead to inflammation of the pericardium, resulting in uremic pericarditis. In the context of uremic pericarditis, initiating or optimizing dialysis is indeed the correct approach. Dialysis can remove the uremic toxins that are likely contributing to the inflammation of the pericardium, thus addressing the underlying cause of the pericarditis. Given the context of chronic renal failure and the absence of specific indications for the other treatments, Dialysis is the appropriate treatment to address uremic pericarditis. This approach aims to reduce the uremic toxins, thereby alleviating the inflammation of the pericardium and resolving the symptoms of pericarditis.
  • • Option B.
  • • Dialysis
  • • Dialysis
  • • Option C. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) : While NSAIDs are the first-line treatment for most cases of acute pericarditis, they may be contraindicated in patients with renal failure due to the risk of further renal injury. In the context of uremic pericarditis, the primary treatment is to improve renal function through dialysis rather than directly targeting the inflammation with NSAIDs.
  • • Option C.
  • • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
  • • Option D. Pericardiocentesis : As before, this is reserved for cases with significant pericardial effusion leading to cardiac tamponade or hemodynamic instability, which does not appear to be the case here based on the normal echocardiogram.
  • • Option D.
  • • Pericardiocentesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key educational point here is to recognize uremic pericarditis as a complication of advanced renal failure and to understand that the primary treatment is improving renal function through dialysis. This approach addresses the underlying cause of the pericarditis by removing uremic toxins from the blood, which are responsible for the inflammation of the pericardium.

questions.text: A physician is reviewing treatment options for a patient diagnosed with visceral leishmaniasis in a tertiary care hospital in India. Which of the following drugs is NOT typically used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)  Hydroxychloroquine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Hydroxychloroquine is used for autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus, not for visceral leishmaniasis. Sitamaquine is under investigation for leishmaniasis.
  • • Paromomycin, an aminoglycoside antibiotic, treats leishmaniasis. Miltefosine is an oral treatment for leishmaniasis.
  • • In VL: Pentavalent antimonials are the DOC except Bihar (Amphotericin B is DOC) In CL: Pentavalent antimonials are the DOC except for L.guyanensis (pentamidine is DOC) and L.ethiopia (paromomycin is DOC)
  • • In VL: Pentavalent antimonials are the DOC except Bihar (Amphotericin B is DOC)
  • • In VL:
  • • In CL: Pentavalent antimonials are the DOC except for L.guyanensis (pentamidine is DOC) and L.ethiopia (paromomycin is DOC)
  • • In CL:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Sitamaquine is an investigational drug for leishmaniasis.
  • • Option
  • • A. Sitamaquine
  • • Option B. Paromomycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic used in the treatment of leishmaniasis.
  • • Option
  • • B. Paromomycin
  • • Option C. Miltefosine is an effective oral treatment for leishmaniasis.
  • • Option
  • • C. Miltefosine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hydroxychloroquine is primarily used for autoimmune diseases like rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus and is not used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis.

questions.text: Can opener’s technique, Envelope technique and continuous circular capsulorrhexis are a part of which surgery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Anterior capsulotomy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Conventional ECCE (Extracapsular Cataract Extraction): These surgical techniques, including the can opener's technique and envelope technique are commonly used in conventional ECCE. In this procedure, the lens is removed intact with its capsule, and intraocular lens implantation may or may not be performed. Continuous circular capsulorrhexis is not particularly associated with conventional ECCE.
  • • Option A. Conventional ECCE (Extracapsular Cataract Extraction):
  • • Option B. Manual SICS (Small Incision Cataract Surgery): Manual SICS involves making a small incision and manually removing the lens nucleus and cortex. While some techniques like can opener's technique and envelope technique may overlap with ECCE, continuous circular capsulorrhexis is less performed in manual SICS compared to phacoemulsification.
  • • Option B. Manual SICS (Small Incision Cataract Surgery):
  • • Option C. Phacoemulsification : Phacoemulsification is a modern cataract surgery technique that utilizes ultrasound energy to emulsify and remove the cataractous lens through a small incision. While continuous circular capsulorrhexis is a key step in phacoemulsification, the other techniques mentioned are not typically associated with this procedure.
  • • Option C. Phacoemulsification
  • • Option D. Anterior capsulotomy : Anterior capsulotomy refers to creating an opening in the anterior capsule of the lens, which is a step performed in various cataract surgeries, including ECCE, SICS, and phacoemulsification. The specific techniques mentioned (can opener's technique, envelope technique, and continuous circular capsulorrhexis) are all associated with Anterior Capsulotomy.
  • • Option D. Anterior capsulotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Understanding the surgical techniques involved in different cataract surgeries is essential for ophthalmologists to choose the appropriate approach based on patient factors and surgical considerations.

questions.text: A mother brings her Five days old baby with a birth weight of 2.5kg for follow up. On examination, the child was alert and active. Icterus is noted. On measuring the baby’s weight, it was found to be 2 kg. Stools were of yellow color. What is the likely cause responsible for the icteric change in the child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

questions.text: In a dramatic turn of events at a large industrial plant, a worker is found lying motionless near a high-voltage electrical panel. The emergency response team rushes to the scene, where they find no visible injuries but the worker is unresponsive and without apparent signs of life. Which of the following scenarios is most likely to result in a state of suspended animation where the victim might appear lifeless but is still alive?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Electrocution

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Suspended animation is when an organism’s bodily functions, like breathing and heartbeat, are drastically slowed down or paused as seen in electrocution.
  • • Suspended animation
  • • Suspended animation
  • • Suspended animation is a condition in which vital signs of life (heart beat and respiration) are not detected by routine clinical methods, as the functions are interrupted for some time or are reduced to a minimum.
  • • Mechanism : The metabolic rate is greatly reduced so that the requirement of the individual cell for oxygen is satisfied through the dissolved oxygen in body fluids
  • • Mechanism
  • • Other options
  • • Other options
  • • Option B. Strangulation/hanging, Option C. Firearm injury and Option D. Burn : suspended animation is not usually seen in these conditions.

questions.text: An 18-year-old with previously regular menses, presents with amenorrhea. She is also diagnosed with anorexia nervosa. Which of the following is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Elevated neuropeptide Y level

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ It has been hypothesized that a decrease in leptin production due to weight loss could secondarily stimulate neuropeptide Y, which is known to stimulate hunger and alter GnRH pulsatility.

questions.text: A 3-month-old male infant is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to acute-onset seizures. The parents report that the infant has been irritable, vomiting, and feeding poorly over the past few days. On physical examination, the infant appears lethargic, has bilateral retinal hemorrhages upon fundoscopic examination, and a bulging anterior fontanelle. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Shaken Baby Syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option D. Shaken Baby Syndrome (SBS) : This is the most likely diagnosis. SBS, also known as abusive head trauma, is a form of inflicted head injury that occurs when an infant is violently shaken. The characteristic radiological findings in SBS include bilateral subdural hematomas, cerebral edema, and often retinal hemorrhages, as described in the scenario. The absence of external signs of trauma with these internal injuries is highly suggestive of SBS. The CT findings mentioned, particularly the bilateral subdural hematomas and cerebral edema, are common in SBS, making this the characteristic radiological finding indicative of severe head trauma in infants.
  • • Option D. Shaken Baby Syndrome (SBS)
  • • Option A . Epidural Hematoma : This is a collection of blood between the dura mater and the skull. It typically results from arterial injury and presents as a biconvex (lens-shaped) hyperdense area on CT scans. Epidural hematomas are less common in infants due to the nature of their head injuries and the anatomy of their skulls and dura. They are more often associated with skull fractures and do not usually present with the combination of symptoms seen in SBS.
  • • Option A
  • • Epidural Hematoma
  • • Option B. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage : This involves bleeding into the subarachnoid space, where cerebrospinal fluid circulates. It can be caused by trauma but is also seen in other conditions like aneurysm rupture. While subarachnoid hemorrhage could be present in head trauma, the specific combination of bilateral subdural hematomas, retinal hemorrhages, and cerebral edema without external trauma is more characteristic of SBS.
  • • Option B.
  • • Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
  • • Option C. Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI) : DAI is a type of traumatic brain injury that involves widespread injury to the brain's white matter. It's typically caused by severe rotational forces or deceleration, not necessarily associated with impact injuries. While DAI can occur in severe head trauma, the CT findings of bilateral subdural hematomas and retinal hemorrhages, along with the clinical presentation, are more indicative of SBS.
  • • Option C.
  • • Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key educational objective is to recognize the signs and radiological findings associated with Shaken Baby Syndrome, a severe form of infant head trauma. Health professionals should be alert to the combination of clinical symptoms like irritability, vomiting, poor feeding, lethargy, retinal hemorrhages, and a bulging fontanelle, along with CT findings of bilateral subdural hematomas and cerebral edema, in the absence of external trauma signs. This knowledge is crucial for the early identification and intervention in cases of suspected infant abuse to prevent further injury and to safeguard the child's well-being.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with a two-week history of dysuria and a clear urethral discharge. He reports no recent sexual contacts and denies any history of similar symptoms. He is afebrile, and a physical examination is unremarkable except for mild urethral erythema. Urine nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs) for Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae returns negative. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)  Mycoplasma genitalium

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Mycoplasma genitalium is a common cause of NGU, especially in cases where tests for C. trachomatis and N. gonorrhoeae are negative. It is increasingly recognized as a pathogen in male urethritis and can be detected with specific NAATs.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. C. trachomatis is a common cause of NGU, but it has been ruled out with negative NAATs.
  • • Option
  • • A. C. trachomatis
  • • Option B. Mycoplasma hominis is not a typical cause of NGU in men.
  • • Option
  • • B. Mycoplasma hominis
  • • Option C. Treponema pallidum causes syphilis, which usually presents with a chancre during primary infection, not urethritis.
  • • Option
  • • C. Treponema pallidum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mycoplasma genitalium is a common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis, particularly when the initial tests for C. trachomatis and N. gonorrhoeae are negative.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man from a rural community in the Thar Desert presents with persistent fever, cough, and weight loss. He also reports painful red nodules on his shins and joint pains. Chest radiography reveals hilar lymphadenopathy. Intradermal testing with a regional fungal antigen is positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)  Cryptococcosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cryptococcosis, caused by Cryptococcus species, is found globally including in India and can cause lung infections and cryptococcal meningitis, particularly in immunocompromised patients such as those with HIV/AIDS. The description of painful red nodules, which could represent cryptococcal cellulitis, and a positive intradermal test with a regional antigen, in this case, may suggest cryptococcal skin involvement which can occur along with pulmonary infection.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Coccidioidomycosis is endemic to the Southwestern United States and parts of Central and South America, not typically found in India.
  • • Option
  • • A. Coccidioidomycosis
  • • Option C. Histoplasmosis is less common in India and would not usually present with erythema nodosum.
  • • Option
  • • C. Histoplasmosis
  • • Option D. Aspergillosis primarily causes respiratory symptoms and is unlikely to cause the systemic symptoms described.
  • • Option
  • • D. Aspergillosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: In a 40-year-old patient with suspected endocrine dysfunction, laboratory tests reveal abnormalities in peptide hormone levels. The endocrinologist is particularly interested in understanding the patient's hormonal profile, focusing on the initial synthesis form of these hormones. Most peptide hormones are synthesised as:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Preprohormone

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Secretagogue is a substance that promotes secretion . This term does not refer to the initial synthetic form of hormones but rather to a function some substances have in stimulating hormone release.
  • • Option A
  • • Secretagogue
  • • substance
  • • promotes secretion
  • • Option B. Pleiotropic Hormone refers to a gene or protein having multiple effects . It's not a term that describes the initial synthesis form of hormones.
  • • Option B.
  • • Pleiotropic Hormone
  • • gene
  • • protein
  • • multiple effects
  • • Option C. Proopiomelanocortin (POMC) is a specific precursor polypeptide . While it is a precursor for several peptide hormones , it's not the general form for the synthesis of most peptide hormones.
  • • Option C.
  • • Proopiomelanocortin (POMC)
  • • specific precursor polypeptide
  • • precursor
  • • several peptide hormones

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize that most peptide hormones are initially synthesized as preprohormones , which are inactive precursors undergoing post-translational modifications to become active hormones .

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to the clinic with multiple well-demarcated, depigmented patches over her elbows and knees. She mentions that the lesions appeared after she had a minor abrasion on her elbow and knees. Her medical history is significant for vitiligo but no other chronic diseases. Which of the following phenomena is most likely responsible for the appearance of her skin lesions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) True Koebner phenomenon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize and understand the true Koebner phenomenon in vitiligo , where depigmented patches may develop at sites of skin trauma , such as minor abrasions. This phenomenon is distinct from the classic Koebner phenomenon seen in psoriasis. Understanding these phenomena is essential for dermatologists in managing and counselling patients with vitiligo.
  • ➤ Recognize and understand the true Koebner phenomenon in vitiligo , where depigmented patches may develop at sites of skin trauma , such as minor abrasions.
  • ➤ true Koebner phenomenon in vitiligo
  • ➤ depigmented patches
  • ➤ trauma
  • ➤ This phenomenon is distinct from the classic Koebner phenomenon seen in psoriasis.
  • ➤ psoriasis.
  • ➤ Understanding these phenomena is essential for dermatologists in managing and counselling patients with vitiligo.
  • ➤ managing and counselling

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with low-grade fever, malaise, and a bright red rash on the cheeks that is sharply demarcated. His mother mentions that the rash seemed to appear following a mild illness with slight fever and runny nose that resolved a few days ago. On examination, there is no lymphadenopathy, and the child appears well otherwise. Laboratory tests show a slight decrease in hemoglobin level and reticulocyte count. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)   Parvovirus B19 infection

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Parvovirus B19 infection commonly presents with the classic "slapped cheek" appearance (erythema infectiosum) in children. This rash is often preceded by a prodromal illness with symptoms such as low-grade fever and upper respiratory tract symptoms. The virus has a particular tropism for erythroid progenitor cells, which can cause a temporary decrease in red blood cell production, leading to a slight anemia and low reticulocyte count.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Rubella - Generally presents with a diffuse maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads downward. It is also associated with tender lymphadenopathy, which was not present in this case.
  • • Option
  • • A. Rubella
  • • Option B. Rubeola (Measles) - Characterized by a high fever, cough, conjunctivitis, coryza, and Koplik spots followed by a descending maculopapular rash. The child in the scenario does not have these symptoms.
  • • Option
  • • B. Rubeola (Measles)
  • • Option D. HHV-6 infection - Causes roseola infantum, which may present with a high fever followed by a rash as the fever subsides. However, the rash in roseola is not described as a "slapped cheek" appearance.
  • • Option
  • • D. HHV-6 infection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The clinical presentation of Parvovirus B19 infection in children is characteristic, with a "slapped cheek" rash following a prodromal illness. Recognition of this rash, along with associated mild anemia and reticulocytopenia, can help in the diagnosis without the need for specific laboratory confirmation.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male lorry driver presented to his local emergency department with a 20-minute episode of diaphoresis and chest pain. The chest pain was central, radiating to the left arm and crushing in nature. The pain settled promptly following 300 mg aspirin orally and 800 mcg glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) spray sublingually administered by paramedics in the community. On examination, he appeared comfortable and was able to complete sentences fully. There were no heart murmurs present on cardiac auscultation. Blood pressure was 180/105 mmHg, heart rate was 83 bpm and regular, oxygen saturation was 97%. He was taken to the catheterization lab where the left anterior descending coronary artery (LAD) was shown to be completely occluded. Which of the following statements is incorrect about LAD?

options.label: A
options.text: The left anterior descending artery lies in the anterior interventricular sulcus

options.label: B
options.text: It is accompanied by great cardiac vein

options.label: C
options.text: It supplies anterior 2/3 of interventricular septum

options.label: D
options.text: It anastomoses with the posterior interventricular branch at the apex of the heart

questions.correct_answer: D. It anastomoses with the posterior interventricular branch at the apex of the heart
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) It anastomoses with the posterior interventricular branch at the apex of the heart

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. The LAD runs down the anterior interventricular sulcus , supplying the sternocostal surface of the heart and the anterior part of the interventricular septum .
  • • Option A.
  • • LAD
  • • down
  • • anterior interventricular sulcus
  • • sternocostal surface
  • • anterior part
  • • interventricular septum
  • • Option B . The LAD is accompanied by the great cardiac vein .
  • • Option B
  • • great cardiac vein
  • • Option C. The LAD provides blood to the anterior 2/3 of the interventricular septum , which includes the bundle branches of the heart's electrical conduction system .
  • • Option C.
  • • anterior 2/3
  • • interventricular septum
  • • bundle branches
  • • electrical conduction system
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Left anterior descending branch anastomose with the posterior interventricular branch of the right coronary artery at the junction of anterior one third and posterior two third of posterior interventricular groove . While the LAD does extend to the apex of the heart , the main anastomosis at the apex is between the terminal branches of the LAD and the posterior descending artery . The PDA is often a branch of the right coronary artery (in right-dominant circulation ) or a branch of the circumflex artery (in left-dominant circulation ).
  • • Left anterior descending branch anastomose with the posterior interventricular branch of the right coronary artery at the junction of anterior one third and posterior two third of posterior interventricular groove .

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about purine analogs?

options.label: A
options.text: Azathioprine is used as immunosuppressant drug.

options.label: B
options.text: Some of these drugs are activated by hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRTase).

options.label: C
options.text: Fludarabine is the drug of choice for CLL.

options.label: D
options.text: Cladribine is degraded by adenosine deaminase.

questions.correct_answer: D. Cladribine is degraded by adenosine deaminase.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cladribine is degraded by adenosine deaminase.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Azathioprine is indeed used as an immunosuppressant drug. It is commonly used to prevent organ rejection after transplantation and in autoimmune diseases.
  • • Option A
  • • Option B . Some purine analogs are activated by hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRTase). This activation is necessary for the drugs to be incorporated into DNA and RNA, which can disrupt the synthesis and repair of these nucleic acids, leading to cell death, particularly in rapidly dividing cells such as cancer cells.
  • • Option B
  • • Option C . Fludarabine is a medication used in the treatment of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and is considered one of the drugs of choice for this condition, especially in patients who are younger and healthier.
  • • Option C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The objective of this question is to assess understanding of purine analogs, their mechanisms of action, and their clinical applications. Cladribine is not degraded by adenosine deaminase; instead, it is resistant to it, which makes statement D incorrect. Other statements are true: Azathioprine is used as an immunosuppressant (A), some purine analogs require activation by HGPRTase to exert their effects (B), and Fludarabine is commonly used in the treatment of CLL (C).

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the clinic with a history of recurrent episodes of wheezing, breathlessness, and chest tightness, especially at night. She reports that these symptoms often get worse during spring. Physical examination reveals high-pitched whistling sounds upon auscultation of the chest. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. Based on her clinical presentation, which type of hypersensitivity reaction is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)  Type 1

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Asthma, particularly allergic asthma as suggested by the patient's symptoms worsening during spring (allergen exposure), is typically due to a Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction. This reaction is IgE-mediated and involves mast cells and basophils. The patient's clinical presentation with wheezing, breathlessness, and chest tightness, which are classic for asthma, support this diagnosis.
  • • Anaphylactic and atopic— two phases :
  • • two phases
  • • Immediate (minutes): antigen crosslinks preformed IgE on pre-sensitized mast cells immediate degranulation release of histamine (a vasoactive amine), tryptase (marker of mast cell activation), and leukotrienes. Late (hours): chemokines (attract inflammatory cells, eg, eosinophils) and other mediators from mast cells inflammation and tissue damage.
  • • Immediate (minutes): antigen crosslinks preformed IgE on pre-sensitized mast cells immediate degranulation release of histamine (a vasoactive amine), tryptase (marker of mast cell activation), and leukotrienes.
  • • Immediate (minutes):
  • • Late (hours): chemokines (attract inflammatory cells, eg, eosinophils) and other mediators from mast cells inflammation and tissue damage.
  • • Late (hours):
  • • Figure: Mechanism of type I hypersensitivity reaction.
  • • Figure: Mechanism of type I hypersensitivity reaction.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Type 2 : This involves IgG or IgM antibodies directed against cell surface antigens, leading to cytotoxicity, commonly seen in conditions like hemolytic anemia.
  • • Option
  • • B. Type 2
  • • Option C. Type 3 : This involves immune complex-mediated reactions, seen in diseases like serum sickness or certain forms of vasculitis.
  • • Option
  • • C. Type 3
  • • Option D. Type 4 : This is a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction mediated by T cells, seen in conditions like contact dermatitis or tuberculin skin test reaction.
  • • Option
  • • D. Type 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A mother from a non-endemic area for hypothyroidism brings her child with failure to thrive, delayed development of milestones, hoarse cry, mottling of skin, with the following facial and abdominal features. What is the most common cause of the child’s condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Thyroid dysgenesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Thyroid dysgenesis is the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism, which presents with failure to thrive, developmental delays, hoarse cry, mottling of the skin, and characteristic physical findings such as umbilical hernia, large tongue, and hypotonia, distinguishing it from thyroid dyshormonogenesis, Hashimoto's thyroiditis, and Graves' disease.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st Edition, Chapter 581, Page No. 11398-11423; Ghai’s Essential Pediatrics, 8 th Edition, Page No. 516-519
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st Edition, Chapter 581, Page No. 11398-11423; Ghai’s Essential Pediatrics, 8 th Edition, Page No. 516-519

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy recently developed weakness of his lower extremity and uses his arms to stand up even though his lower legs appear quite muscular. Laboratory tests reveal a creatine kinase level of 20,000 U/L. A DNA test confirms the working diagnosis. What is the function of the altered gene product in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Exocytosis of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction

questions.correct_answer: B. Linking actin filaments to laminin
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Linking actin filaments to laminin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option B. Linking actin filaments to laminin : This is the correct answer. Dystrophin is part of a complex of proteins that connects the internal cytoskeleton of a muscle fibre (specifically, the actin filaments) to the surrounding extracellular matrix through the cell membrane. By anchoring the actin cytoskeleton to the cell membrane, dystrophin helps maintain the integrity and stability of the muscle fibre during contraction.
  • • Option B.
  • • Linking actin filaments to laminin
  • • Option A. Exocytosis of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction : This process is critical for the initiation of muscle contraction, but it is not the function of the dystrophin protein. The release of acetylcholine is a function of the presynaptic nerve terminal at the neuromuscular junction.
  • • Option A.
  • • Exocytosis of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction
  • • Option C. Promoting actin-myosin cross-bridge cycling : Actin-myosin cross-bridge cycling is the fundamental process of muscle contraction, involving the interaction between actin and myosin within the muscle fibres. While dystrophin is associated with the actin filaments, its primary role is not to promote this cycling but to provide structural stability to the muscle fibres.
  • • Option C.
  • • Promoting actin-myosin cross-bridge cycling
  • • Option D. Receptor for acetylcholine : The acetylcholine receptor is located on the muscle cell membrane at the neuromuscular junction and is responsible for transducing the neural signal into a muscular contraction. Dystrophin is not involved in this receptor function.
  • • Option D.
  • • Receptor for acetylcholine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand the function of dystrophin in muscle cells and its role in Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy. Dystrophin is essential for linking the internal cytoskeleton of muscle cells to the extracellular matrix, providing structural stability to muscle fibres during contraction. The absence or deficiency of dystrophin leads to the progressive muscle weakness and degeneration seen in DMD.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male with a known history of diabetes presents to the emergency department with severe right upper quadrant abdominal pain and fever. He reports experiencing intermittent abdominal pain and nausea for the past few weeks, but the current episode is more severe. On examination, he is febrile with a temperature of 102.5°F (39.2°C) and has tenderness in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, with a positive Murphy's sign elicited during the physical examination. Laboratory investigations reveal an elevated white blood cell count, elevated liver enzymes, and an elevated blood glucose level. A non-contrast computed tomography (NCCT) scan of the abdomen and right upper quadrant is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Emphysematous cholecystitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option D. Emphysematous cholecystitis : This is the most likely diagnosis. Emphysematous cholecystitis is a severe form of acute cholecystitis characterized by gas formation in the gallbladder wall and lumen, often due to infection by gas-forming organisms. It is more common in diabetic patients and presents with severe right upper quadrant pain, fever, and elevated inflammatory markers. The presence of gas would be identifiable on an NCCT scan of the abdomen, distinguishing it from other forms of cholecystitis. The severe presentation, coupled with the patient's diabetic status, makes this diagnosis particularly likely.
  • • Option D. Emphysematous cholecystitis
  • • Option A. Calculous cholecystitis : This is the inflammation of the gallbladder due to the obstruction of the cystic duct by gallstones. While the patient's symptoms of right upper quadrant pain, fever, and a positive Murphy's sign are consistent with acute cholecystitis, the presence of gas in the gallbladder wall or lumen on the NCCT scan, if mentioned, would point more specifically toward emphysematous cholecystitis rather than the more common calculous cholecystitis.
  • • Option A.
  • • Calculous cholecystitis
  • • Option B. Acute pancreatitis : This condition involves inflammation of the pancreas and presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, elevated pancreatic enzymes, and findings on imaging studies. While abdominal pain and elevated enzymes are present in this patient, the right upper quadrant pain and positive Murphy's sign are more characteristic of gallbladder pathology than pancreatitis.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Acute pancreatitis
  • • Option C. Choledocholithiasis : This refers to the presence of one or more gallstones in the common bile duct. Symptoms can include right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and possibly cholangitis if there is associated infection. While the patient's liver enzyme abnormalities could suggest bile duct involvement, the clinical picture and imaging findings are more suggestive of gallbladder disease, particularly emphysematous cholecystitis, given the patient's diabetic status and severe presentation.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Choledocholithiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key educational objective is to recognize the clinical features and diagnostic criteria for emphysematous cholecystitis, especially in diabetic patients presenting with severe right upper quadrant pain, fever, and specific findings on NCCT. It's important to distinguish this condition from other causes of abdominal pain such as calculous cholecystitis, acute pancreatitis, and choledocholithiasis, using clinical assessment, laboratory investigations, and imaging studies. Emphysematous cholecystitis is a surgical emergency requiring prompt diagnosis and management due to its high morbidity and mortality rates.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after she sustained an injury to the right knee while roller-blading. The patient says she felt sudden, severe pain in the knee when she turned a corner quickly. She fell to the ground and was unable to bear weight on the right leg. Physical examination shows swelling and deformity of the right knee as well as inability to fully extend and straighten the right lower extremity. X-ray studies show dislocation of the patella. In addition to administration of analgesics, which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.correct_answer: C. Closed reduction of the patella
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)  Closed reduction of the patella

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option C. Closed Reduction of the Patella : This is the initial treatment of choice for an acute patellar dislocation. It involves manually manipulating the patella back into its normal position. It's a non-surgical method and is usually performed under analgesia to relieve pain and muscle spasm.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Closed Reduction of the Patella
  • • Option A. Arthroscopic Lateral Release : This procedure involves cutting the tight lateral structures to balance the patella within the trochlear groove. It's more commonly used in chronic patellar instability rather than acute dislocations.
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • Arthroscopic Lateral Release
  • • Option B. Arthroscopic Medial Plication : This surgical procedure involves tightening the medial structures to stabilize the patella. Like the lateral release, it's typically indicated in cases of recurrent patellar instability, not for an acute dislocation.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Arthroscopic Medial Plication
  • • Option D. Open Reduction of the Patella : This is a surgical approach used if closed reduction is unsuccessful or if there are associated injuries that need repair (such as osteochondral fractures). However, it's not typically the first line of treatment for an isolated acute patellar dislocation.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Open Reduction of the Patella

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For acute patellar dislocation, closed reduction is the initial management of choice. Surgical interventions are typically reserved for cases where closed reduction is unsuccessful or for recurrent dislocations. Early and appropriate management is crucial for minimizing discomfort and preventing further injury.

questions.text: A primigravida at 8 weeks is found to have mild anemia. On evaluation, she is detected to be beta-thalassemia minor. Her husband is also found to have the thalassemia trait. What investigation would you advise her next?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chorionic villous sampling

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Beta Thalassemia major is an autosomal recessive condition in which both the beta globin genes are defective, and no beta chains are produced If the mother has thalassemia trait (beta thalassemia minor), the father’s status is checked. If the father also has the beta thalassemia trait, there is a 25% (1 in 4 chance) the fetus has beta thalassemia major. Prenatal diagnosis is done by Chorionic villous sampling (CVS) in the 1 st trimester OR Amniocentesis in the 2 nd trimester

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman complains that she has not had a period for 3 months. Four home pregnancy tests have all been negative. She started her periods at the age of 15 years and until 30 years she had a normal 28-day cycle. She had one daughter by normal delivery 2 years ago, following which she breast-fed for 6 months. After that she had normal cycles again for several months and then her periods stopped abruptly. She was using the progesterone-only pill for contraception while she was breastfeeding and stopped 6 months ago as she is keen to have another child. She reports symptoms of dryness during intercourse and has experienced sweating episodes at night as well as episodes of feeling extremely hot at any time of day. There is no relevant gynaecological history. The only medical history of note is that she has been hypothyroid for 10 years and takes thyroxine 100 mg per day. She does not take any alcohol, smoke or use recreational drugs. On lab investigation, FSH level is 45 IU/L. What is the diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Delay in return of fertility after contraception

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Premature ovarian failure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Premature ovarian failure is a type of Hypergonadotrophic hypogonadism in which premature menopause occurs before the age of 40 years and is characterized by increased FSH levels

questions.text: A third-year medical student is preparing a presentation on the history and development of modern medical practices. While researching, the student discovers the concept of Evidence-Based Medicine (EBM), a systematic approach to clinical problem-solving which allows the integration of the best available research evidence with clinical expertise and patient values. Intrigued by the transformative impact of EBM on healthcare, the student seeks to acknowledge the pioneer of this approach in their presentation. Who is recognized as the father of Evidence-Based Medicine?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sackett

Explanation:

  • • Explanation -
  • • Father of Evidence based medicine (EBM): David Sackett (1934 - 2015)
  • • Father of Evidence based medicine (EBM):
  • • Founded first Department of Clinical Epidemiology in Canada Founded Oxford Centre for EBM Wrote books : Clinical Epidemiology Evidence Based Medicine
  • • Founded first Department of Clinical Epidemiology in Canada
  • • Founded Oxford Centre for EBM
  • • Wrote books : Clinical Epidemiology Evidence Based Medicine
  • • Wrote books
  • • Clinical Epidemiology Evidence Based Medicine
  • • Clinical Epidemiology
  • • Evidence Based Medicine
  • • Other Options –
  • • Other Options –
  • • Option B. Da Vinci : Leonardo da Vinci was a Renaissance polymath who made significant contributions to a wide range of areas including art, science, and engineering.
  • • Option B. Da Vinci
  • • Option C. Hippocrates : the "Father of Medicine," Hippocrates was an ancient Greek physician who made significant contributions to the field of medicine. His "Hippocratic Oath" is still referenced today as an ethical guide for medical practitioners.
  • • Option C.
  • • Hippocrates
  • • Option D. Tolstoy : Leo Tolstoy was a Russian writer best known for his novels such as "War and Peace" and "Anna Karenina." He is not linked to the field of medicine.
  • • Option D. Tolstoy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Sackett is to Evidence-Based Medicine as Hippocrates is to the foundations of Medicine.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the physician with diabetes mellitus, osteoporosis, and hypertension. She has noted a recent weight gain and abdominal striae. Laboratory studies show a decreased ACTH level. A single mass is noted adjacent to the right kidney on abdominal CT scan. Neither low- nor high-dose dexamethasone suppresses the patient’s cortisol production. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Adrenal adenoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option A. Adrenal adenoma : This is a benign tumor of the adrenal gland that can autonomously produce cortisol, leading to Cushing's syndrome. The decreased ACTH level in this patient suggests a primary adrenal source of excess cortisol (due to negative feedback on the pituitary gland), making an adrenal adenoma a likely explanation for these findings. Adrenal adenomas typically do not respond to dexamethasone suppression, as their cortisol production is autonomous. Given the presence of an adrenal mass, decreased ACTH levels, and cortisol production that is not suppressed by dexamethasone, the most likely explanation for these findings is Adrenal adenoma .
  • • Option A.
  • • Adrenal adenoma
  • • Adrenal adenoma
  • • Option B. Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia : This condition is usually caused by excessive ACTH production stimulating both adrenal glands, leading to their enlargement and increased cortisol production. However, this patient has decreased ACTH levels, which makes bilateral adrenal hyperplasia less likely since it typically involves elevated or normal ACTH levels due to an ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma (Cushing's disease) or ectopic ACTH secretion.
  • • Option B.
  • • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia
  • • Option C. Ectopic ACTH secretion : This occurs when a non-pituitary tumor secretes ACTH, leading to bilateral adrenal hyperplasia and increased cortisol production. Common sources include small cell lung cancer and neuroendocrine tumors. Ectopic ACTH secretion typically presents with elevated ACTH levels, not decreased levels as seen in this patient, making this option less likely.
  • • Option C.
  • • Ectopic ACTH secretion
  • • Option D. Exogenous corticosteroid administration : Prolonged use of corticosteroids can lead to Cushing's syndrome due to the exogenous supply of glucocorticoids. This condition would also present with decreased ACTH levels due to negative feedback. However, the presence of an adrenal mass on CT scan and the clinical context does not support this option as the primary explanation for her symptoms.
  • • Option D.
  • • Exogenous corticosteroid administration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key educational objective is to understand the diagnostic approach to Cushing's syndrome and differentiate its causes based on clinical and laboratory findings. In cases of Cushing's syndrome with a single adrenal mass and decreased ACTH levels, an adrenal adenoma is a likely cause. This condition is characterized by autonomous cortisol production by the adrenal adenoma, leading to the suppression of ACTH production due to negative feedback mechanisms.

questions.text: A 2-year-old female child was brought by her parents with delayed developmental milestones and pain in lower limbs and difficulty in walking for 3 months. O/E, child had stiffness of joints in both upper and lower limbs and has coarse facial features, low IQ and hepatomegaly. Urinary examination reveals presence of heparan sulfate and dermatan sulphate. Fibroblast study reveals deficiency of enzyme iduronate-2-sulfatase. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Hunter’s Disease

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents with four days of progressive, bilateral, lower extremity weakness and dysesthesia. The patient denies any history of trauma, but states that he stayed home from work last week because of fever accompanied by diarrhea. Neurologic examination demonstrates the absence of reflexes in the lower extremities with no cranial nerve deficits. What is the best therapy for this patient’s condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Plasmapheresis and immunoglobulin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option A. Plasmapheresis and immunoglobulin : This is the correct answer. Both plasmapheresis (plasma exchange) and intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) are established treatments for Guillain-Barré syndrome. These therapies are thought to modulate the immune response and remove pathogenic antibodies and other immune mediators from the circulation, which can help halt the progression of the disease and potentially speed up recovery. The choice between plasmapheresis and IVIG is often based on availability, medical comorbidities, and patient preference, as they are considered equally effective for GBS.
  • • Option A.
  • • Plasmapheresis and immunoglobulin
  • • Option B. Glucocorticoids : While glucocorticoids are commonly used to treat a variety of autoimmune and inflammatory conditions, they have not been shown to be effective in the treatment of Guillain-Barré syndrome and are not recommended as a treatment for GBS.
  • • Option B.
  • • Glucocorticoids
  • • Option C. Acetaminophen : While acetaminophen can be used to manage fever and mild pain, it does not address the underlying immune-mediated process of Guillain-Barré syndrome and is not considered a treatment for the condition itself.
  • • Option C.
  • • Acetaminophen
  • • Option D. Radiation therapy : Radiation therapy is a treatment modality used primarily for cancer and certain non-malignant conditions, but it is not a treatment for Guillain-Barré syndrome, which is an autoimmune disorder affecting the peripheral nervous system.
  • • Option D.
  • • Radiation therapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To recognize the clinical presentation of Guillain-Barré syndrome and understand the appropriate treatment options. Guillain-Barré syndrome is an acute, immune-mediated polyneuropathy that can follow infectious illnesses, and prompt treatment with either plasmapheresis or intravenous immunoglobulin can improve outcomes by modulating the immune response.

questions.text: Which of the following medical procedures would require the use of the instrument shown in the image? To hold the fundus of the gall bladder To hold drapes in surgical field To grasp the products of conception To hold the spermatic cord To hold the cervix

Remove laminated membrane and daughter cysts : During the surgical treatment of hydatid cyst, these forceps are utilized to delicately remove laminated membranes and daughter cysts. Open Cholecystectomy : They play a crucial role in holding and manipulating the fundus and Hartmann's pouch of the gall bladder during cholecystectomy surgeries. Swab abscess cavity : Sponge holding forceps are used to swab and clean abscess cavities, ensuring thorough disinfection and drainage. Cerclage : In obstetrics, these forceps can be employed to hold the cervix in place during cerclage procedures, providing precise control and support.
  • • Clean skin : They are employed to clean the skin using a swab dipped in antiseptic solution before and during surgical procedures to maintain a sterile field.
  • • Clean skin
  • • Remove laminated membrane and daughter cysts : During the surgical treatment of hydatid cyst, these forceps are utilized to delicately remove laminated membranes and daughter cysts.
  • • Remove laminated membrane and daughter cysts

  • • Open Cholecystectomy
  • • Swab abscess cavity : Sponge holding forceps are used to swab and clean abscess cavities, ensuring thorough disinfection and drainage.
  • • Swab abscess cavity
  • • Cerclage : In obstetrics, these forceps can be employed to hold the cervix in place during cerclage procedures, providing precise control and support.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to her family physician for a routine check-up. She exhibits mild mental retardation. Physical examination shows an oval-shaped, slightly pigmented nevus on the lower back and an angiofibroma on the forehead that the patient reports having had since birth. The patient has a history of a cardiac rhabdomyoma that spontaneously regressed in childhood. A previous MRI showed multiple nodules of glial proliferation in the basal ganglia, ventricles, and cortex. This patient most likely also has which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Epilepsy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option C. Epilepsy : Given the patient's history and clinical features suggestive of tuberous sclerosis complex, the most likely associated condition she also has is Epilepsy . This is a common neurological manifestation of TSC, affecting up to 90% of individuals with the condition. The presence of multiple nodules of glial proliferation in the brain, as mentioned, can lead to seizures, making epilepsy a likely associated condition.
  • • Option C.
  • • Epilepsy
  • • Epilepsy
  • • Option A. Bilateral hearing loss : While TSC can affect various organs, it is not typically associated with bilateral hearing loss as a direct consequence of the disease.
  • • Option A.
  • • Bilateral hearing loss
  • • Option B. Central scotoma : A central scotoma is a loss of vision in the central visual field, which can occur in various eye diseases but is not a hallmark feature of TSC.
  • • Option B.
  • • Central scotoma
  • • Option D. Severe sun sensitivity : While some skin manifestations in TSC may be exacerbated by sun exposure, severe sun sensitivity is not a characteristic feature of this condition, as it would be in disorders specifically affecting DNA repair mechanisms in response to UV light, such as xeroderma pigmentosum.
  • • Option D.
  • • Severe sun sensitivity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To recognize the clinical features of tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) and its neurological manifestations. TSC is a genetic disorder that can cause benign tumors in multiple organs, including the brain, where they can lead to epilepsy. Understanding the multi-organ involvement of TSC is crucial for diagnosis, management, and surveillance for associated complications, including seizures.

questions.text: After a high fever for 4 days, a 27-year-old man becomes delirious, and his friends bring him to the emergency room. Physical examination reveals a cardiac murmur, along with splenomegaly and a temperature of 38.7°C. Splinter hemorrhages appear under the nails of both his hands. Echocardiography reveals the lesions seen here. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Intravenous drug use

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option B. Intravenous drug use:
  • • Option B. Intravenous drug use:
  • • Intravenous drug use is associated with an increased risk of infective endocarditis, which is an infection of the heart valves or lining of the heart. It is often caused by bacteria entering the bloodstream through contaminated needles or paraphernalia. Patients with infective endocarditis can present with cardiac murmurs, splenomegaly, and other systemic symptoms, making this option a likely diagnosis.
  • • Intravenous drug use is associated with an increased risk of infective endocarditis, which is an infection of the heart valves or lining of the heart. It is often caused by bacteria entering the bloodstream through contaminated needles or paraphernalia. Patients with infective endocarditis can present with cardiac murmurs, splenomegaly, and other systemic symptoms, making this option a likely diagnosis.
  • • Option A. Acute rheumatic fever:
  • • Option A. Acute rheumatic fever:
  • • Acute rheumatic fever is an autoimmune inflammatory condition that can affect various parts of the body, including the heart. It typically occurs as a result of untreated streptococcal throat infections (streptococcal pharyngitis). It can lead to carditis (inflammation of the heart), which may result in heart murmurs and other cardiac manifestations. However, the presentation in this case does not fit the typical pattern of acute rheumatic fever.
  • • Acute rheumatic fever is an autoimmune inflammatory condition that can affect various parts of the body, including the heart. It typically occurs as a result of untreated streptococcal throat infections (streptococcal pharyngitis). It can lead to carditis (inflammation of the heart), which may result in heart murmurs and other cardiac manifestations. However, the presentation in this case does not fit the typical pattern of acute rheumatic fever.
  • • Option C. Congenital bicuspid valve:
  • • Option C. Congenital bicuspid valve:
  • • A congenital bicuspid valve is a heart valve anomaly in which the aortic valve has two leaflets instead of the normal three. While bicuspid valves can be prone to dysfunction and may require surgical intervention, they are not typically associated with the specific findings seen in this patient's case, such as splinter hemorrhages and intracardiac lesions.
  • • A congenital bicuspid valve is a heart valve anomaly in which the aortic valve has two leaflets instead of the normal three. While bicuspid valves can be prone to dysfunction and may require surgical intervention, they are not typically associated with the specific findings seen in this patient's case, such as splinter hemorrhages and intracardiac lesions.
  • • Option D. Trousseau syndrome:
  • • Option D. Trousseau syndrome:
  • • Trousseau syndrome, also known as migratory thrombophlebitis, is a condition characterized by recurrent thrombophlebitis (inflammation of veins) and is often associated with an underlying malignancy. It does not typically involve cardiac lesions or endocarditis-related symptoms.
  • • Trousseau syndrome, also known as migratory thrombophlebitis, is a condition characterized by recurrent thrombophlebitis (inflammation of veins) and is often associated with an underlying malignancy. It does not typically involve cardiac lesions or endocarditis-related symptoms.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intravenous drug use is a significant risk factor for the development of infective endocarditis, a condition characterized by infection of the heart valves or lining of the heart. Prompt diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent complications associated with infective endocarditis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is admitted to the hospital after sustaining fractures of his right femur and tibia in a motor vehicle collision. The Patient becomes agitated, hypervigilant, and paranoid 12 hours after admission. He Repeatedly tells the nurses that he can hear people in the corridor making insulting remarks about him. When hospital staff check the area near the patient's room, no one is found. Medical history is unremarkable, but psychiatric history is significant for cocaine, marijuana, and alcohol misuse. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes a day for the past 10 years. On examination, the patient is alert and oriented. Temperature is 37.2⁰C (99⁰F), blood pressure is 135/87 mm Hg, pulse is 85/min, and respirations are 18/min. He is slightly tremulous and diaphoretic. Within 2 days, the patient's hallucinations resolve, and his behavior returns to baseline. Soon after, he is discharged home. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Alcoholic hallucinosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option A: Alcoholic hallucinosis. This patient's history of alcohol misuse, lack of premorbid psychosis, and acute onset of auditory hallucinations shortly after hospitalization (i.e., with abrupt cessation of alcohol) are most consistent with alcoholic hallucinosis. Alcoholic hallucinosis is an alcohol withdrawal syndrome characterized by hallucinations and relatively stable vital signs in an otherwise alert and oriented patient. Alcoholic hallucinosis typically presents after 12 hours of abstinence and resolves within 48 hours after the last drink. The condition is usually self-limited but can be managed with benzodiazepines.
  • • Option A:
  • • Alcoholic hallucinosis.
  • • Option B: Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by sudden-onset psychotic symptoms lasting ≥1 day and ≤1 month. It isa rare disorder that can be diagnosed only after psychosis due to substance intoxication/withdrawal or a medical condition is ruled out. This patient's onset of hallucinations 12 hours following hospitalization, along with a history of alcohol abuse, is more suggestive of alcohol withdrawal-induced psychosis (i.e., alcoholic hallucinosis).
  • • Option B:
  • • Brief psychotic disorder
  • • Option C: Cocaine withdrawal causes depression, anxiety, fatigue, and intense cravings. It is not commonly associated with psychosis.
  • • Option C:
  • • Cocaine withdrawal
  • • Option D: Delirium tremens, which does not present prior to 48 hours after the last drink, is characterized by disorientation and marked sympathetic hyperactivity (e.g., hyperthermia, hypertension, tachycardia). This patient is alert and oriented, his vital signs are normal, and his hallucinations fully resolved before 48hours (i.e., hospital day 2).
  • • Option D:
  • • Delirium tremens,
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Alcoholic hallucinosis is an alcohol withdrawal syndrome that typically present after 12 hours of abstinence and resolves within 48 hours after the last drink. Unlike delirium tremens, it tends to present in patients who are fully oriented and with relatively stable vital signs.

questions.text: In a hospital laboratory setting, proper disposal of medical waste is paramount to ensuring safety and preventing contamination. A new laboratory technician is being trained on the protocols for disposing of various types of laboratory waste, including used vacutainers which are commonly used for blood collection. The technician learns that different colors of disposal containers and bags are designated for specific types of waste according to standard biomedical waste management guidelines. Based on these guidelines, in which of the following disposal containers should used vacutainers be discarded?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Red bag

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Red category contains Contaminated Waste (Recyclable) including wastes generated from disposable items such as vacutainers but without needles.
  • • disposable items
  • • BMW category
  • • BMW category

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Under NEW Biomedical Waste Management Guidelines 2016-17, Red bag is used for disposal of Contaminated Waste (Recyclable)
  • ➤ It includes wastes generated from disposable items such as tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles and fixed needle syringes) and vaccutainers (with their needles cut) and gloves

questions.text: An ENT Surgeon while doing singular neurectomy for intractable BPPV, has cut its parent nerve accidentally. Which other structure is supposed to lose its sensory supply now, apart from posterior semicircular canal?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Macule of saccule

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cristae of superior semicircular canal : The cristae of the superior semicircular canal are innervated by the superior vestibular nerve, a branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve. This structure would not be directly affected by a singular neurectomy.
  • • Option A. Cristae of superior semicircular canal
  • • Option B. Cristae of lateral semicircular canal : The cristae of the lateral semicircular canal are also innervated by the superior vestibular nerve. Thus, it would not lose sensory supply due to injury to the nerve associated with the singular nerve.
  • • Option B. Cristae of lateral semicircular canal
  • • Option C. Macula of saccule : The macula of the saccule is innervated by the inferior vestibular nerve, the same division of the vestibulocochlear nerve as the singular nerve. The saccule is sensitive to vertical acceleration and gravity. If the parent nerve of the singular nerve is cut, it implies that the inferior vestibular nerve is compromised, affecting the macula of the saccule.
  • • Option C. Macula of saccule
  • • Option D. Macula of utricle : The macula of the utricle is primarily innervated by the superior vestibular nerve. It is responsible for sensing horizontal acceleration. This structure would not be affected by damage to the singular nerve or its parent nerve within the context of the inferior vestibular nerve.
  • • Option D. Macula of utricle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In the context of singular neurectomy for intractable BPPV, accidental cutting of its parent nerve (the inferior vestibular nerve) would lead to a loss of sensory supply to the macula of the saccule, in addition to the posterior semicircular canal. This educational objective underscores the importance of understanding the innervation of the inner ear structures.

questions.text: A 29-year-old G2P1 woman at 28 weeks’ gestation, who had normal haemoglobin level 4 weeks ago at her first prenatal visit, complains of 1 week of fatigue and now has a haemoglobin level of 7.0 g/ dL. She noted dark-coloured urine after taking an antibiotic for a urinary tract infection. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) G6PD deficiency anemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) is an enzyme found in the cytoplasm of all cells in the body. It is a housekeeping enzyme that plays a vital role in the prevention of cellular damage from reactive oxygen species (ROS). It does this by providing substrates to prevent oxidative damage. Erythrocytes are particularly vulnerable to ROS due to their role in oxygen transport and inability to replace cellular proteins as mature cells. Inherited deficiencies of G6PD can result in acute hemolytic anemia during times of increased ROS production. This may be caused by stress or exposure to certain foods that contain high amounts of oxidative substances, for example, fava beans, or certain medications (antimalarials, antibiotics etc.).
  • ➤ Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) is an enzyme found in the cytoplasm of all cells in the body.
  • ➤ It is a housekeeping enzyme that plays a vital role in the prevention of cellular damage from reactive oxygen species (ROS).
  • ➤ It does this by providing substrates to prevent oxidative damage.
  • ➤ Erythrocytes are particularly vulnerable to ROS due to their role in oxygen transport and inability to replace cellular proteins as mature cells.
  • ➤ Inherited deficiencies of G6PD can result in acute hemolytic anemia during times of increased ROS production.
  • ➤ This may be caused by stress or exposure to certain foods that contain high amounts of oxidative substances, for example, fava beans, or certain medications (antimalarials, antibiotics etc.).

questions.text: A 12-year-old female with an unremarkable past medical history presents with fever, sore throat, and a tender cervical lymphadenopathy.
